THE FARMER AND HIS SON S8A
DOWN BELOW IN THE PALACE GARDEN 1265

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mangy, bone-thin DOG lopes across the broad valley floor, sniffing at the ground. At first the scene appears bucolic: tall grass, patches of wildflowers, blue sky above. But as the dog keeps running we see signs of conflict. A spear, half imbedded in the earth, rises at an angle. A bronze helmet, cracked and bloodied, lies on its side. The dog pauses to sniff the helmet then continues his search. Finally he stops, hackles on his back rising, ears pricked up. He growls, and we see what the dog sees. Dozens of CROWS have descended into a shallow ravine. They squabble and peck, clustered around something on the ground. The dog growls louder and charges at the crows. The black birds flap away to safety, shrieking in protest. A DEAD SOLDIER lies facedown in the ravine. Whatever armor he wore was stripped away, leaving his body to the elements. The dog walks slowly to the dead man, sniffing at the corpse's hands. The dog whines and licks the man's fingers. Something in the air disturbs the dog, who looks up. And now we hear it, faintly, in the distance. HOOF BEATS and chariot wheels, marching men, the clank of bronze armor and weaponry. The dog runs, abandoning his dead master.

dialogues.speaker: THE MYCENAEAN ARMY 1A
dialogues.text: five thousand strong, storms into the valley from the south. Armored with bronze breastplates, helmets and shields, the soldiers glitter in the morning sun. Riding alongside the infantry are dozens of horse-drawn CHARIOTS, each holding a DRIVER, a SPEARMAN and an OFFICER. On the opposite side of the valley, three thousand THESSALONIAN SOLDIERS march into view. The Thessalonians are less disciplined, their armor and weaponry less impressive. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: When each army reaches the battlefield they stop and star one another down, two hundred yards distant.

dialogues.speaker: A MYCENAEAN CHARIOT AND A THESSALONIA CHARIOT 1B
dialogues.text: emerge from their respective sides and meet at the center of the field. AGAMEMNON, king of the Mycenaeans, rides in his chariot with a DRIVER and a SPEARMAN. Agamemnon holds a gold SCEPTER, symbol of command. His breast plate is engraved with an Alpha. His counterpart in the Thessalonian cart, TRIOPAS (60), does not project equal confidence. He eyes the size of the Mycenaean army with evident unease. He holds his own SCEPTER. Both kings step down from their chariots and approach eac other. They stare at one another for several seconds. Agamemnon smiles and looks into the sky. The crows wheel overhead, cawing.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: It's a good day for the crows.

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: I told you yesterday and I'll tell you again today. Remove your army from my land. Agamemnon smiles again and turns to examine the valley.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I like your land. I think we'll stay. (beat) I like your soldiers, too. They fought bravely yesterday. Not well, but bravely.

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: They'll never fight for you.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: That's what the Messenians said, too. And the Arcadians. And the Epeians. They're all fighting for me, now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: You can't rule the whole world, Agamemnon. It's too big. Even for you. Agamemnon surveys Triopas's army.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I don't want to watch another massacre. Let's end this war in the old manner. (beat) Your best fighter against my best. For the first time, Triopas looks hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: And if my man wins?

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: We'll leave Thessaly for good. (beat) I'm a generous man. If mine wins, you keep your throne. But Thessaly falls under my command, to fight with me whenever I call. Triopas considers before nodding. He shouts to his army.

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: Boagrius! The Thessalonians murmur and step aside. A giant emerges from their midst, BOAGRIUS, a foot taller than the other men, his face gouged with old knife scars. He marches out to his king.

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: Here is my champion. Agamemnon raises his eyebrows as the giant comes closer.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: (shouting to his army) Achilles! The Mycenaeans murmur amongst themselves, looking for Achilles. Nobody emerges. Agamemnon frowns.

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: Boagrius has this effect on many heroes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Be careful whom you insult, old king. An OFFICER on horseback gallops from the Mycenaean ranks to the center of the field. He bows his head to Agamemnon.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Achilles is not with the army. Triopas laughs and looks up at Boagrius, who chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: (furious) Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: I sent a boy to look for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BOY (12) on a roan HORSE gallops through the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy rides into the camp. Scores of tents stand on the banks of a river. The only men around are COOKS tending fires and ARMORERS, mending armor and weapons. The boy dismounts at one large tent in the corner of the camp. He pulls open the tent flap and steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy pauses for a moment inside the tent, eyes adjusting to the dim light. Evidently last night was a wild party. Jugs of wine are everywhere, and the remains of a large feast. Sleeping on a fur rug are two NAKED WOMEN and one NAKED MAN, tanned arms and legs entwined. The boy sidesteps shards of a broken jug. He bends to tap the sleeping man's shoulder. Before his fingers make contact, a hand shoots out, grabs his wrist, and pulls him to the rug. The boy finds himself flat on his back with a dagger to his throat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Shh. The boy stares into the eyes of ACHILLES (30), who seems to have barely moved. Somehow he managed to seize the boy and put a knife to his throat without waking the women.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: (whispering) I was having a good dream. (beat) A very good dream. The boy nods, dumb with fear. Achilles has the lean, efficient physique of a boxer. His face and body are dark from a summer spent in the sun.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: King Agamemnon sent me. He needs --

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I'll speak with your king in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: But my lord -- it is morning. Achilles frowns. He stands and walks naked to the tent flap, holds it open and stares at the empty encampment.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: They're waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles prepares for battle, strapping on his breastplate. The boy assists him, fixing the bronze greaves to his legs.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Are the stories about you true? They say your mother is an immortal goddess. Achilles lifts up his shield. He slips his left forearm into the leather straps on the inside of the shield.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: They say you can't be killed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be bothering with the shield then, would I?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: The Thessalonian you're fighting -- he's the biggest man I've ever seen. Achilles mounts the boy's horse.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to fight him.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: That's why no one will remember your name. Achilles gallops away, leaving the boy standing alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agamemnon confers with his OFFICERS on the battlefield, including KING NESTOR (65), his trusted advisor. When Achilles rides into view the Mycenaean soldiers CHEER. Some cry out his name. Agamemnon and his officers turn to watch Achilles dismount and approach them.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should have our war tomorrow, when you're better rested? Achilles ignores the king and examines the waiting giant.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I should have you whipped for impudence. Achilles wheels on the king.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Who's giving the whipping? He walks toward Agamemnon, fingers curling over the hilt of his sword. Nestor slides in between Achilles and the king.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: Achilles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Achilles, nostrils flared, eyes narrowed, stares at Agamemnon. Neither man is willing to turn away.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: (to Agamemnon) Why don't you fight him yourself? Wouldn't that be a sight, a king who fights his own battles?

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: Achilles. Achilles finally turns and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: Look at the men's faces. Achilles surveys the faces of the battle-weary soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: You can save hundreds of them. You can end this war with a swing of your sword. (beat) Think how many songs they'll sing in your honor. (beat) Let them go home to their wives. The soldiers, awed in his presence, stare at Achilles. He finally turns and walks toward Boagrius. Agamemnon watches Achilles with undisguised hostility.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: (to Nestor, under his breath) Of all the warlords loved by the gods, I hate him most.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: We need him, my king.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: For now.

dialogues.speaker: 6A ACHILLES 6A
dialogues.text: When Achilles is forty yards from the giant, Boagrius turns to his army and shakes his spear over his head. They cheer, slamming their bronze swords against their bronze shields. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Achilles keeps coming. He looks up at the circling crows. Boagrius turns and throws his spear. The bronze spearhead glitters in the sun, blazing straight for Achilles. Without breaking stride, Achilles raises the shield. The spearhead blasts through the bronze skin of the shield, through the thick leather on the underside, stopping inches from Achilles' face. Achilles keeps coming. Boagrius hoists a second spear and hurls it, grunting wit effort. Again Achilles raises his shield, again the spearhead tears through the shield but does not harm Achilles. Achilles casts aside the shield and keeps coming. Boagrius unsheathes his tremendous bronze sword. He opens his mouth, lets loose a battle cry, and charges at Achilles. When Boagrius raises his sword, Achilles lunges forward with terrifying speed. It does not seem possible that he could close the gap between them so quickly, but he does, thrusting his sword straight through Boagrius' breastplate. Achilles pulls his sword from the giant's chest and continues walking toward the Thessalonian line, never looking back. Boagrius stares down at the hole in his breastplate. Blood pumps out, pouring down the polished bronze. He topples over. The Mycenaean Army ERUPTS with exultant victory cries. Achilles now stands in front of the massed Thessalonian troops. He searches from face to face. None of the soldiers are willing to make eye contact with him. Finally Triopas steps out of the ranks.

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: Who are you, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Achilles, son of Peleus. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: Achilles. I won't forget the name. Triopas offers Achilles the heavy gold SCEPTER.

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: The ruler of Thessaly carries this scepter. Give it to your king.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: He's not my king. Achilles walks west, away from both armies. The soldiers watch him go in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're high above the wine-dark sea, gliding north. Soon the Peloponnesian coast comes into view. The only break in the shoreline is the inlet of Laconia, and we follow i inland. The inlet ends in a natural harbor where several tall- masted warships are beached, sails unfurled, oars locked and rowing benches empty. Dozens of smaller fishing boats are scattered about the harbor. On top of the highest hill, overlooking all Sparta, stand a thick-walled PALACE. Torch-bearing SENTRIES, wearing plumed helmets and carrying long spears, man their posts.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Princes of Troy, on our last night together, Queen Helen and I salute you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MENELAUS (40), king of Sparta, stands at the head of a massive table that spans the length of a hall lit by torches. A battle-scarred warrior, Menelaus is already halfway drunk. Beside Menelaus sits his wife, HELEN (25), wearing a whit gown, head bowed, half listening to her husband. Fresh flowers are woven into her hair. Her beauty is so extreme she seems to exist in a separate realm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The only woman in the room and the only one wearing white Helen shines amidst the unwashed WARRIORS of Sparta and Troy. All sit at a table laden with platters of roasted game birds, whole fish, octopi, suckling pigs and bowls o fruit. Menelaus holds his gold wine goblet in the air, toasting his honored guests, HECTOR (35) and PARIS (25). Hector is not the best-looking man in the room, nor the largest, but the intensity of his expression, the regalit of his bearing, confirms that he is a born leader. Paris is the best-looking man in the room, by a long shot He's not paying attention to Menelaus. He's staring at Helen.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: We've had our conflicts before, it's true. We've fought many battles, Sparta and Troy. And fought well! Menelaus's soldiers cheer drunkenly. For a moment Helen looks up and meets Paris's gaze.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: But I've always respected your father. Priam is a good man, a good king. I respected him as an adversary, and I respect him now as my ally. More cheering, this time from the entire assembly.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Hector, Paris, young princes, come, stand, drink with me. Hector stands. Paris does not. He's still staring at Helen. Hector nudges his brother's shoulder. Paris stands.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Let us drink to peace. Hector nods to Menelaus and raises his cup.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Peace between Troy and Sparta. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The king and the princes drink deeply and slam their empt cups to the table.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: May the gods keep the wolves in the hills and the women in our beds. All the men in the hall cheer and rise to their feet.

dialogues.speaker: GUESTS
dialogues.text: To Sparta! To Troy! A band of MUSICIANS strike up their instruments; SERVANTS roam the hall filling goblets with wine. POLYDORA (20), one of Helen's handmaidens, leads a dozen attractive YOUNG WOMEN into the banquet hall. The warriors howl at the sight of the women. Soon each of the handmaidens is flanked by drunken soldiers. Menelaus grabs Hector in a bear hug. Hector gamely accepts the embrace. When the king releases him, both men spill a few drops of wine from their cups onto the floor. They drink the rest of their wine. Menelaus grips Hector's upper arm. SERVANTS refill the cups.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: A strong arm. Thank the gods we made peace -- I've seen too many of my men struck down with this arm.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Never again, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Only one man works a sword better than you. The son of Peleus the Argonaut.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: That madman would throw a spear at Zeus himself if the god insulted him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Menelaus indicates Polydora, who stares at Hector openly.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: You see that one over there? I picked her just for you. She's a little lioness. Menelaus grins at the girl, who lowers her eyes and smiles. Helen notices this silent exchange but ignores it, conversing instead with another HANDMAIDEN who sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Thank you. My wife waits for me in Troy.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: My wife waits for me right there. He leans forward to whisper conspiratorially in Hector's ear.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Wives are for breeding. You understand? For making little princes. Come, enjoy yourself tonight. Helen stands and walks out of the reception hall. Menelaus does not notice. Hector does. He raises his cup to Menelaus.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You make excellent wine in Sparta. Menelaus laughs and drinks with Hector. Paris excuses himself from the Spartan generals he's been speaking with and heads outside -- in the same direction as Helen. Hector watches with mounting agitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is lit by a dozen tall candles. Helen removes the flowers from her hair and drops them into a bowl of water. She hears a sound and looks up. Paris stands in the doorway. For several breaths they are silent, staring at each other. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be here. Paris closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: That's what you said last night.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Last night was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: And the night before? Helen continues removing the flowers from her hair but sh cannot hide a half-smile.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I've made many mistakes this week. He approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Do you want me to go? His hands are on her now, sliding down her bare neck, dow her back, resting on her hips. His mouth is very close to her ear. Helen closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (whispering) Yes. Paris kisses her neck, her ears, her closed eyes. The tightness we saw in her face when she sat by her husband' side is gone, replaced by ecstasy.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: (whispering) Where should I go? She kisses him back now and there's a hunger in her kisses, something close to violence in her desire. She lifts off his tunic and pulls him nearer.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (whispering) Away. Far away. In a moment the white gown slips to her feet. He stares at her naked body in wonder. He opens his mouth to speak but she kisses him full on the lips. They sink onto the bed.  10 il 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As more and more wine gourds are emptied, the scene grows rowdier. An impromptu choir of Spartan and Trojan soldiers drunkenly sing battle songs. Polydora sits on Menelaus's lap. She whispers in his ear while he laughs and drains another cup of wine. Bits of roasted boar fleck his thick red beard. Hector sits nearby, half engaged in conversation with several Spartan generals. He's clearly not happy that his brother's still missing. INT. HELEN'S CHAMBER - NIGHT (LATER) il Helen lies naked on her bed. In the candlelight her flanks are mapped with copper trails of sweat. She watches Paris, who stands bedside pulling on his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I have something for you. From his tunic he pulls a necklace of baby pearls threade with silver. He sits beside her in bed.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Pearls from the sea of Propontis. Paris strings the pearls around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: They're beautiful. (beat) But I can't wear them. Menelaus would kill us both.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid of him.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid of dying. I'm afraid of tomorrow, watching you sail away and knowing you'll never come back. She runs her fingers across his jaw line.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Before you came to Sparta I was a ghost. I walked and I ate and I swam in the sea, but I was a ghost. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il 12 15. CONTINUED: il

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: You don't have to fear tomorrow. Helen watches him, unsure what he means.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Come with me. For a long moment they stare into each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Don't play with me, prince of Troy. Don't play. The sounds of footsteps and laughter outside the door startle them. Paris halfway unsheathes a KNIFE hanging from his belt. Whoever's walking by the door passes without stopping. Paris sheathes his knife, kneels beside the bed and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: If you come we'll never be safe. Men will hunt us and the gods will curse us. But I'll love you. Until the day they burn my body I will love you. Helen stares into Paris' eyes, contemplating the impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of TROJAN SOLDIERS lies on goatskins and furs around a bonfire built in the middle of the courtyard. Some sleep; some continue to drink and sing old Trojan songs. Hector stands by the fire, conferring with TECTON (30), a bull-necked captain of the elite Apollonian Guard.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Make the proper offerings to Poseidon before we sail. We don't need any more widows in Troy.

dialogues.speaker: TECTON
dialogues.text: Goat or pig?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Which does the Sea God prefer? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TECTON
dialogues.text: (smiling) I'll wake the priest and ask him. Tecton bows and exits the courtyard. Hector sees Paris slinking past the bonfire, sneaking toward his quarters.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Paris! Paris turns, smiles and waves, acting as if he hadn't see Hector before. He ambles over to join his brother.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You should get to bed. We won't sleep on land again for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I have no trouble sleeping on the seas. The sea nymphs sing lullabies to me.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: And who sang lullabies to you tonight? Paris freezes for a moment but quickly regains his poise.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Tonight? Tonight was the fisherman's wife. A lovely creature.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I hope you didn't let the fisherman catch you.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: He's more concerned with the fish. Paris smiles and starts to walk away but Hector holds him

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You do understand why we're in Sparta?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: For peace. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: And you do understand that Menelaus, King of Sparta, is a powerful man? And that his brother, Agamemnon, King of Mycenae, commands all the Greek forces?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: What does this have to do with the fisherman's wife? Hector seizes Paris's face between the palms of his hand. Not a violent gesture, exactly, but not gentle, either.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Paris. You're my brother, and I love you. But if you do anything to endanger Troy I'll rip your pretty face from your pretty skull. He kisses Paris on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Get some sleep. We sail in the morning. Paris, a bit shocked by the encounter, stumbles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TROJAN SHIP sails over the waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winds are strong. Nobody needs to row. SAILORS tend the sails or play dice. Hector stands in the bow, leaning against the rail, whittling a WOODEN LION. Paris joins him.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: A beautiful morning. Poseidon has blessed our voyage. Hector looks at the blue sky for a moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Sometimes the gods bless you in the morning and curse you in the afternoon. Paris watches his brother work the wood. When Paris speaks again his tone is more sober than we've heard it before.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Do you love me, brother? Hector rests his knife on the deck and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: What have you done now?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I need to show you something. Paris walks toward the staircase leading inside the ship. Hector watches him for a few seconds and then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris pauses in front of his cabin door.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Before you get angry with me --

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Open the door. Paris opens the door. Helen, wearing a hooded robe, sits on the edge of a hammock, swinging slightly. She stands. Hector stares at her in disbelief. He turns and glares at Paris.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: If you weren't my brother I'd kill you where you stand.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Hector -- Hector is already out the door. Helen looks at Paris.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: We'll never have peace.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I don't want peace. I want you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He kisses her -- a desperate, hungry kiss, the two of the against the world -- then turns and follows his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menelaus, followed by ten SOLDIERS, storms into Helen's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds Polydora polishing the queen's jewelry. Menelaus grabs her arm roughly. She's terrified.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: POLYDORA
dialogues.text: Who, my king? Menelaus draws his sword.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: I swear by the father of the gods I'll gut you here if you don't tell me. The handmaiden tries to speak but no words come out. Fortunately for her, HIPPASUS, (50), a royal advisor, enters the room at that moment followed by an old FISHERMAN (65).

dialogues.speaker: HIPPASUS
dialogues.text: She left with the Trojans, my king. Menelaus stares at Hippasus, who swallows and gestures at the fisherman. The fisherman looks as if he'd rather be fishing.

dialogues.speaker: HIPPASUS
dialogues.text: The old man saw her board their ship. Menelaus releases the handmaiden and stares at the fisherman.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: The Trojans? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: With the young prince. Paris. She -- Menelaus holds up his hand. The fisherman shuts up. Everyone watches the king, waiting for an explosion, but the news -- strangely -- seems to focus him.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Get my ship ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector walks quickly toward the stern, Paris right behind him. The PILOT mans the rudder.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: (to pilot) Turn us around. Back to Sparta.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Wait, wait. Hector spins on his brother.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You fool.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Listen to me -- Hector shoves his brother backwards. The older brother's physical power is obvious. SAILORS watch in awed silence.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Do you know what you've done? Do you know how many years our father worked for peace? How many brothers and cousins he lost on the battlefield?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I love her. The muscles in Hector's jaw bulge against his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Say another word and I'll break your arm. This is all a game for you, isn't it? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: al. 18

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You roam from town to town, bedding merchants' wives and temple maids - - you think you know something about love? What about your father's love? You spat on him when you brought her on this ship. What about love of your country? You'd let Troy burn for this woman. Paris starts to speak but Hector raises a warning finger.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I won't let you start a war for her.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: May I speak? (beat) What you say is true. I've wronged you. I've wronged our father. If you want to bring Helen back to Sparta, so be it. But I go with her.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: To Sparta? They'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Then I'll die fighting. Hector laughs bitterly. He grabs the collar of Paris's tunic.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: That sounds heroic to you, doesn't it? To die fighting. Tell me, little brother, have you ever killed a man?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Have you ever even seen a man die in combat?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: No. Hector's face is flushed with anger. Paris tries to look away but Hector won't let him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I've killed men, brother. I've watched them dying, I've heard them dying, I've smelled them dying. (beat) There's nothing glorious about it, nothing poetic. You think you want to die for love, but you know nothing about dying. You know nothing about love.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: All the same, I go with her. Hector releases his brother. He stares at the sea.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I won't ask you to fight my war. Hector shakes his head, still staring into the waves.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You already have. For a long time Hector is silent. Finally he turns to the pilot, who awaits the prince's command.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: To Troy. Hector walks away from his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three WARSHIPS are anchored in the harbor. Menelaus, followed by Hippasus and a retinue of SOLDIERS, climbs the long stone staircase that leads to the walled city of Mycenae, a citadel hewn from the hilltop rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menelaus and his followers enter the throne room. Treasures from various conquests fill the room: statuary and urns and intricate gold work. Armed GUARDS stand at their posts. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Only Agamemnon is seated, on a beautiful throne carved from solid oak. Two robed NOBLES are addressing him when Menelaus enters -- they move away as the Spartans approach. Agamemnon stands. The two kings embrace.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Your messenger came two days ago. I know what happened. Menelaus's face darkens, his rage barely submerged.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: I want her back.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Of course you do. She's a beautiful woman.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: I want her back so I can kill her with my own two hands. I won't rest until I've burned Troy to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: (smiling) I thought you wanted peace with Troy.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: I should have listened to you.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Peace is for the women and the weak. Empires are forged by war.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: All my life I've stood by your side, fought your enemies. You're the eldest, you reap the glory -- this is the way of the world. But have I ever complained, brother? Have I ever asked you for anything?

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Never. You're a man of honor. Everyone in Greece knows this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: The Trojans spat on my honor. An insult to me is an insult to you.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: And an insult to me is an insult to all Greeks.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Will you go to war with me, brother? Menelaus reaches out his hand. Agamemnon looks into his eyes. Finally he nods and clasps hands with his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agamemnon paces the vast, torch-lit room. Nestor sits at a wooden table. Spread out on the table before him is a rough map of Greece and environs, painted on a tanned goa skin.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I always thought my brother's wife was a foolish woman. But she's proven to be very useful. Nothing unifies a people like a common enemy.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: The Trojans have never been conquered. Some say they can't be conquered.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I haven't tried yet. (beat) Old King Priam thinks he's untouchable behind his high walls. He thinks the Sun God will protect him. But the gods only protect the strong. (points at map) If Troy falls, I control the Aegean.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: Hector commands the finest army in the east. And Troy is built to withstand a ten-year siege. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: al
al

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: There won't be a ten-year siege. I'll attack them with the greatest force the world has ever seen. I want all the kings of Greece and all their armies. (beat) Send emissaries in the morning. Nestor stands and prepares to leave. Agamemnon

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: One last thing. (beat) We need Achilles and his Myrmidons. shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Achilles can't be controlled. He's as likely to fight us as the Trojans.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: We don't need to control him. We need to unleash him. The man was born to end lives.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Yes, he's a gifted killer, but he follows no king. He threatens everything I've built. (beat) Before me Greece was nothing, a province of warlords and cattle raiders. I've brought all the Greek kingdoms together -- with the sword when necessary, with a treaty when possible. I've created a nation out of fire-worshippers and snake-eaters. (beat) I build the future, Nestor. Achilles is the past, a man who fights for no flag, a man loyal to no country. Nestor waits a respectful moment before replying. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: al 22 26. CONTINUED: (2) al

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: Your words are true. But how many battles have we won off the edge of his sword? (beat) This will be the greatest war the world has ever seen. We need the greatest warrior. Agamemnon thinks about it, pacing the room. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: There's only one man he'll listen to.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: I'll send a ship in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lean, bearded SHEPHERD (40) sits on a hillside looking over the Ionian sea. Beside him sits his faithful hunting dog, ARGOS. They watch a troop of EMISSARIES climb the steep hill. The emissaries are panting for breath by the time they reach the hilltop.

dialogues.speaker: EMISSARY
dialogues.text: Greetings, brother. We were told King Odysseus is here in the hills.

dialogues.speaker: SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Odysseus? That old bastard drinks my wine and never pays.

dialogues.speaker: EMISSARY
dialogues.text: You ought to respect your king, friend.

dialogues.speaker: SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Respect him? I'd like to punch him in the nose. He's always pawing at my wife, trying to tear her clothes off. The emissaries, embarrassed, begin walking away. The shepherd watches them go. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: (to Argos the dog) I hope Agamemnon's generals are smarter than his emissaries. Emissary #1 turns to look at the shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: EMISSARY
dialogues.text: What did you say? The shepherd scratches behind Argos's ears. The dog wags his tail happily.

dialogues.speaker: SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You want me to help you fight the Trojans.

dialogues.speaker: EMISSARY
dialogues.text: You're -- Emissary #1 exchanges glances with his compatriots. They're confused. Finally the chastened emissaries bow.

dialogues.speaker: EMISSARY
dialogues.text: Forgive us, King Odysseus. Odysseus stands and looks down at his dog.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Well, I'm going to miss my dog.

dialogues.speaker: EMISSARY
dialogues.text: King Agamemnon has a favor to ask of you. Odysseus smiles and rubs his dog's head.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Of course he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles stands in the ruins of an ivy-covered temple on cliff above the sea, sparring with his cousin Patroclus (17). Both men wield wooden practice swords. Patroclus is a talented, lean, flashy young fighter. His sword whirls in the air like a thing alive. Achilles, by contrast, is the apotheosis of the efficient combatant, wasting no energy, waiting for weakness. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Patroclus presses in on the attack. Achilles tilts his head to avoid one thrust, side-steps to avoid another. Spying a momentary opening he lunges forward and taps Patroclus' belly with the tip of his wood sword.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You're getting fat, cousin. Patroclus grins and relaunches his attack, sword spinning with blazing speed. Achilles ducks beneath an arcing swing and sword-taps Patroclus on the back.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Fancy swordplay. The girls must be impressed. Patroclus grunts and charges in again. This time a genuine duel develops, featuring splendid repartee and parrying.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: A little nervous, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Terrified. Achilles raises his right hand and Patroclus lifts his sword to parry the blow -- but Achilles no longer holds his sword in his right hand. Sword in hisleft hand, Achilles taps Patroclus on the chest. Patroclus stares down at the wood blade.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: You told me never to switch sword hands. Achilles rolls his head to loosen his neck.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: By the time you know how to do it, you won't be following my orders anymore. Achilles tosses aside the sparring sword. He cocks his head as if listening to some distant sound. Patroclus, oblivious to the noise, practices his swordplay. Achilles' foot curls around the wood shaft of one of the spears lying on the ground. In one impossibly fast motion, he flips the spear into the air with his foot, catches it, and throws in the opposite direction from where he was looking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The bronze warhead blazes between the temple's walls and drives into the trunk of an old fir. Only now do we see Odysseus, leading a black horse, standing inches from the quivering shaft of the spear blocking his path. He stares at the spear for a moment before ducking his head under the shaft and walking forward.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: (smiling) Your reputation for hospitality is fast becoming legend.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I don't like that smile, my friend. It's the smile you smile when you want me to fight in another war. (beat) Patroclus, my cousin -- Odysseus, king of Ithaca.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Patroclus, son of Menoetius? The boy nods. Odysseus grips Patroclus's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: I knew your parents well. I miss then. Patroclus nods again, looking at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Now you have this one watching over you, eh? Learning from Achilles himself -- every boy in Greece must be jealous. (to Achilles) We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Tell me you're not here at Agamemnon's bidding. Odysseus hesitates. Achilles shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: How many times have I done the savage work for the King of Kings? And when has he ever shown me the respect I've earned? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you to fight for him. I'm asking you to fight for the Greeks.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Why? Are the Greeks tired of fighting each other?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: For now.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: The Trojans never did anything to me.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: They insulted Greece.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: They insulted one Greek, a man who couldn't hold on to his wife. What business is that of mine?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Your business is war, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: (angry) Is it? Am I the whore of the battlefield? Can my sword be bought and sold? (beat; calmer) I don't want to be remembered as a tyrant's mercenary.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Forget Agamemnon. Fight for me. My wife will feel much better if she knows you're by my side. I'll feel much better.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: Is Ajax going to fight in Troy?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Of course. You've heard of Ajax, eh?

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: They say he can fell an oak tree with one swing of the axe. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ol.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Trees don't swing back. Odysseus chuckles, but he's alert to the boy's enthusiasm Patroclus

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: We're sending the largest fleet that ever sailed -- a thousand ships.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: A thousand ships! Prince Hector, is he as good a warrior as they say?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: The best of all the Trojans. Some say he's better than all the Greeks, too. (beat) Even if your cousin doesn't come, Patroclus, I hope you'll join us. We could use a strong arm like yours. beams with pride and looks at his cousin. Achilles wraps his arm around Odysseus's shoulders and leans closer to the Ithacan. The embrace is friendly, but there's no mistaking the power in Achilles' grip.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Play your tricks on me, if you'd like. But leave my cousin out of it.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: You have your sword, I have my tricks. We play with the toys the gods give us. Odysseus goes back to his horse and mounts. Patroclus,

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: We sail for Troy in three days. (beat) This war will never be forgotten. Nor will the heroes who fight in it. eager but frustrated, watches him ride away.  24 25 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles makes his away across the sandy hillocks. He spies a woman in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles finds his mother, THETIS (45), standing in the surf. Her long black hair is streaked with gray. She sees a shell that she likes and stoops down to pick it up

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Mother. Thetis turns and smiles at Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: THETIS
dialogues.text: I thought I'd make you another seashell necklace.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I haven't worn a seashell necklace since I was a boy. Thetis looks at Achilles' bare neck.

dialogues.speaker: THETIS
dialogues.text: Don't you like them anymore? Achilles spots a good shell. He hands it to his mother.

dialogues.speaker: THETIS
dialogues.text: Oh, that's a pretty one. She surveys the beach for more pretty shells.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: They want me for another war. Thetis bends down and scoops up a silvery shell.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: THETIS
dialogues.text: Yes, my sweet. Another war.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Patroclus wants to go.

dialogues.speaker: THETIS
dialogues.text: Patroclus has never seen war. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Thetis examines the shells in the palm of her hand. Finally she stands and looks at her son.

dialogues.speaker: THETIS
dialogues.text: If you stay here, with me, with your family, you'll have a long, peaceful life. You'll marry, you'll have children, and your children will have children. They'll love you, and when you're gone they'll remember you. But when your children are dead, and their children after them, your name will be lost. Thetis reaches up to touch her son's cheek. Her eyes are clear, her voice steady. She speaks these lines with no hesitation, no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: THETIS
dialogues.text: If you go to Troy, no one will earn more glory than you. Men will tell stories of your victories for thousands of years. The world will remember your name. Achilles stares at her, his eyes burning. These are words he's wanted to hear since the day he was born. His mother waits a moment before speaking again. The words hurt her.

dialogues.speaker: THETIS
dialogues.text: But if you go to Troy, you'll never come home. You'll die there.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: And you know this, mother?

dialogues.speaker: THETIS
dialogues.text: I know it. Achilles looks out to the sea. Thetis, tears in her eyes, smiles bravely.

dialogues.speaker: THETIS
dialogues.text: Whenever your father came home from war, he'd stare at the sea, just like that. (beat) He never stayed for long. In the distance Achilles sees a white sail. He fixates on the lonely spot of white on the endless expanse of dark water.  26 27 28 29 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We soar above the greatest armada the world has ever seen ONE THOUSAND SHIPS sail east, crowding the sea, churning the waves with their keels. The white sails are painted with the signs and emblems of the various nationalities represented in this alliance. One ship sails slightly out of formation. Alone amongst the entire fleet, this ship's sail is black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles stands in the prow of his boat, staring east. Patroclus stands behind him, wearing a new SHELL NECKLACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector, Paris, Helen, and an entourage of SOLDIERS walk through the gates of Troy. The city is magnificent, a wonder of white-washed walls, lush gardens, and towering STATUES of the gods. ZEUS, APOLLO, APHRODITE, and POSEIDON stand eighty feet high in the four corners of the main square. The princes' return is a holiday for the Trojans. Thousands of ONLOOKERS line the road, cheering. Other well-wishers, standing on the roofs of houses, throw flower petals. Paris holds Helen's hand and occasionally whispers in her ear, pointing out various sights, but Helen looks nervous People in the crowd, mystified by her appearance, point a her and whisper amongst themselves. Helen holds her head high and pretends to ignore the murmurs and stares. Hector looks at her. She carries herself like a queen -- but she's gripping Paris's hand with white knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bottom of a long staircase leading into the palace four APOLLONIAN GUARDS, wearing horsehair-plumed helmets, are mounted on beautiful WHITE HORSES. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hector reunites with his wife, ANDROMACHE (30), pale skinned and dark eyed. He holds her to his chest; she closes her eyes, and they stand like that for a long time A NURSE standing nearby holds Hector's ten-month-old son, SCAMANDRIUS. Now Andromache takes the baby from the nurse. Hector stares into the boy's wondering eyes and puts his finger in the boy's hand.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: He has a good grip.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: He's just like his father. He even hates peas. While this reunion is going on, Paris embraces his father PRIAM (70), king of Troy. Priam is a regal-looking man with a shock of white hair and sharp blue eyes. He adores Paris.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Father, this -- is Helen. Helen bows her head, paying respect.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Helen? Helen of Sparta? Both Helen and Priam now look at Paris.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Helen of Troy. If Priam is disturbed by this revelation, his face doesn' betray it. He leans forward and kisses the former queen on both cheeks. Helen didn't know what to expect -- she's flustered and gratified at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: I've heard rumors of your beauty. For once, the gossips were right. Welcome.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Thank you, good king.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Come, you must be tired. He leads them up the stairs and into the palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRISEIS, a seventeen-year-old girl with an aristocratic demeanor, wearing the white robes of a temple acolyte, approaches the royal family. Paris smiles when he sees her.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Briseis! Beloved cousin, your beauty grows with each new moon. Briseis, cheeks flushing, dips her knees in deference. Hector approaches her now, arms open. Briseis's face lights up. She hugs the eldest prince. Hector kisses the top of her head.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Did you miss me, little swan? Briseis nods. Hector pinches the sleeve of her robe.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: A servant of Apollo now?

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: The young men of Troy were devastated when she chose the virgin robes. Briseis' cheeks turn bright red.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Uncle. Priam laughs and kisses the girl's forehead. He takes three goblets of wine from a SERVANT holding a silver platter and hands them to Hector and Paris, keeping one for himself.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: I thank the gods for your safe return. The king and the princes spill a few drops of wine.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM, HECTOR AND PARIS
dialogues.text: For the gods! They drain their goblets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera glides down the long hall, past tall columns and marmoreal depictions of the Olympians. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: At the far end of the hall, Priam stands by an open archway looking over the city. Hector sits at a table that could seat fifty men.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: It's the will of the gods. Everything is in their hands. (beat) But I'm surprised you let him bring her.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: If I'd let him fight Menelaus for her, you'd be burning a son's body instead of welcoming a daughter. Priam closes his eyes at these words.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: We could send peace envoys to Menelaus.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You know Menelaus. He'd spear your envoys! heads to his gate.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: What would you have me do?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Put her on a ship and send her home. Priam thinks for a moment, staring out at his city.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Women have always loved Paris and he's loved them back. (beat) But this is different. Something has changed in him. If we send her back to Menelaus, he'll follow. Hector stands and joins his father in the archway. He gestures outside. The city of Troy teems with life, the CITIZENS going about their business.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: This is my country. These are my countrymen. I don't want to see them suffer so my brother can have his prize. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) It's not just the Spartans coming after her. By now Menelaus has gone to Agamemnon, and Agamemnon's wanted to destroy us for years. Once we're out of the way he controls the seas.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Enemies have been attacking us for centuries. Our walls still stand.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Father. (beat) We can't win this war.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Apollo watches over us. Even Agamemnon is no match for the gods.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: How many battalions does the Sun God command?

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Don't mock the gods. Hector opens his mouth to argue but holds his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: When you were very young you came down with scarlet fever. Hector nods impatiently. He's heard this story before.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Your little hands were so hot. The healer said you wouldn't last the night. I went down to Apollo's temple and I prayed until the sun came up. (beat) That walk back to the palace was the longest of my life. But I went into your mother's room and you were sleeping in her arms. The fever had broken. (beat) I promised that day to dedicate my life to the gods. I will not break my promise. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hector takes a deep breath. He knows Priam has decided.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: For thirty years I've worked for peace. Thirty years. (beat) Paris is a fool sometimes. I know that. But I'll fight a thousand wars before letting him die. Hector looks past the city to the sea. The waters are empty now, but he knows what's coming.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Forgive me, father. But you won't be the one fighting. He bows and leaves the old king alone in the great hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris paces about the room. Helen stands in the archway looking out to the dark sea. The wind blows through her hair.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: They're coming for me. (beat) The wind is bringing them closer. Paris stops pacing and stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: What if we left? Tonight, right now, what if we went down to the stables, took two horses and left. Ride east, keep riding --

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: And go where?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Away from here. I could hunt deer, rabbit. I could feed us.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: This is your home --

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: You left your home for me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Sparta was never my home. My parents sent me there when I was sixteen to marry Menelaus, but it was never my home. Paris, excited with his new-hatched plan, barely listens.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: We'll live off the land. No more palaces for us, no more servants. We don't need any of that.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: And your family?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: We'd be protecting my family! If we're not here there's no need for a war.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Menelaus won't give up. He'll track us to the end of the world.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: He doesn't know these lands. I do. We can lose ourselves in a day. Helen stands and kisses him on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You don't know Menelaus. You don't know his brother. They'll burn every house in Troy to find us. They'll never believe we've left -- and even if they do, they'll burn Troy for spite. Paris considers her words and finally nods.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Then I'll make it easy for him to find me. I'11l walk right up to him and tell him you're mine. Helen wraps her arms around Paris and rests her chin on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You're very young, my love. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: We're the same age!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You're younger than I ever was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rises above Troy and the Trojan countryside.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MAIN SQUARE 335A
dialogues.text: dozens of SUPPLICANTS kneel before the statue of Poseidon and lay down their offerings: bundles of flowers; small carvings; goatskins filled with wine.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIERS 335B
dialogues.text: prepare a series of fortifications at the beach. Men carrying torches ignite giant pumice urns filled with burning pitch. Others hammer long spikes deep into the sand to hinder enemies rushing up from the beach. There is little conversation and the men look tense. Everything is touched with an air of extreme urgency.

dialogues.speaker: A TEMPLE OF APOLLO 33C
dialogues.text: overlooks the beach.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE TEMPLE 33D
dialogues.text: two PRIESTS carve strips of fat from a roasted PIG and la them on the god's altar, muttering chants as they perform the ritual. Briseis, the temple acolyte, stands beside the priests, pouring ceremonial wine on the stone floor.

dialogues.speaker: MERCHANTS 33E
dialogues.text: in the marketplace set up their stalls and display their goods: wine, olive oil, dates, figs, nuts and spices. The BRONZESMITH hammers a bronze sword into shape.  ooF

dialogues.speaker: 33H
dialogues.text: 34 o4A

dialogues.speaker: A SHEPHERD S3F
dialogues.text: watches over his herd of SHEEP.

dialogues.speaker: A FARMER AND HIS SON 33G
dialogues.text: lead a team of yoked OXEN to the fields.

dialogues.speaker: FOUR FISHERMEN 33H
dialogues.text: in a small boat, a mile from shore, spread their nets in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two SENTRIES stand in a guard tower on a corner of Troy's city walls, sipping hot broth from bowls. A large flag, emblazoned with Troy's HORSE EMBLEM, flies above the tower. Sentry #1 blows steam off his soup. He raises his eyes, blinks and squints into the distance. He bolts upright. Sentry #2 stands and follows his partner's gaze out to th sea. Both of them stand slack-jawed.

dialogues.speaker: A THOUSAND GREEK WARSHIPS 34A
dialogues.text: clog the horizon, sailing straight for Troy.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: grabs a gong tapper and begins hammering the brass gong hanging from the tower's lintel. Sentry #1 still stares at the swarm of ships. No Trojan has ever seen such a force.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRIES 34C
dialogues.text: in other guard towers hammer their warning gongs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector sits on a rug by his bed, beside his wife Andromache, watching his son. The boy plays with the WOOD LION Hector carved on the journey back from Sparta. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The city bells begin to ring. Hector looks at his wife and walks to the balcony, where he can see over the city walls to the Aegean. He sees a thousand enemy sails. For a moment he stares at the armada before hurrying back into the palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priam kneels before a grand statue of Zeus in the great hall. The Thunder God, his stone face a mask of rage, thunderbolts clutched in his stone hands, stares down at the old king. Listening to the bells, Priam takes a deep breath and Loo into Zeus's eyes. The father of the gods stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panic in the streets of Troy. Merchants quickly pack away their goods; mothers run into the streets looking for their children; young men hurry to the armory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mad rush to get inside the safety of the city walls.

dialogues.speaker: THE FARMER AND HIS SON S8A
dialogues.text: hastily load provisions onto a wagon.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHEPHERD 38B
dialogues.text: hurries his herd toward the Trojan gates. He's joined by hundreds of COUNTRY DWELLERS racing for sanctuary.

dialogues.speaker: THE FISHERMEN 38C
dialogues.text: row desperately for shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The armada draws closer to shore. One ship sails far ahead of the rest. Its sail is black.  40 Al 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles' OARSMEN holler encouragement to their shipmates and check to see that their boat is safely in the lead. Achilles stands in the prow, scanning the Trojan shore. Patroclus stands beside him. EUDORUS (40), a Myrmidon lieutenant, approaches Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Should we wait for the others? Achilles marks the progress of the other ships. The nearest is a quarter-mile back. Those MYRMIDONS (Achilles' countrymen and comrades) not rowing are suiting up for battle.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: They brought us here for a war, didn't they?

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Yes, my lord. But Agamemnon -- Achilles stares at his officer until the man bows his head.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Do you fight for me, Eudorus? Or Agamemnon?

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: For you, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Then fight for me. And let the servants of Agamemnon fight for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agamemnon, Nestor and Menelaus stand in the ship's prow.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Whose ship is that? Nestor shields his eyes from the sun and looks. Nestor Black sail. Achilles. They watch Achilles' ship approach the beach. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: What is that fool doing? He's going to take the beach of Troy with fifty men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TROJAN ARCHERS check their catgut strings one last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tecton dismounts at the door of the armory and runs inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cavernous building is crowded with armaments: racks and racks of spears, swords, breastplates, and shields. Hector watches as hundreds of male CITIZENS rush into the armory and are issued weapons by TROJAN SOLDIERS. The faces of the men reflect fear, excitement, and resolve. Tecton approaches the prince and bows.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: The Apollonian Guard?

dialogues.speaker: TECTON
dialogues.text: Waiting at the city gates.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Good. Hector grabs the captain, LYSANDER, overseeing arms distribution.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: How long before the army is ready?

dialogues.speaker: LSYANDER
dialogues.text: Half our men are still coming in from the countryside. We have to arm them, we have to match them with the right officers --

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: How long? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LSYANDER
dialogues.text: (taking a deep breath) Noon?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Make it sooner. We've never seen the prince in martial mode before. He looks different: eyes harder, mouth set and unsmiling.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I want patrols to scour the countryside. Check every home, every pasture. I want every Trojan brought inside the walls. If they can't walk, carry them. Lysander bows his head. Hector walks swiftly away, followed by Tecton. Lysander and the other Trojans watch their prince with silent respect. There is no doubt who leads the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though the oarsmen continue to pull, everyone is now armored. Achilles sees Patroclus, armed and ready to fight.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: To fight the Trojans. Achilles shakes his head and takes Patroclus' spear.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You're not ready.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: I am ready. You taught me how to fight. Achilles rests his hand on the back of the boy's head.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: And you're a good student. But you're not a Myrmidon yet. He gestures to the Myrmidons around them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 46 4вЂќ Al.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: These are the fiercest soldiers in Greece. Each of them has bled for me before. (beat) I can't fight the Trojans if I'm worrying about you, cousin. Guard the ship. Patroclus looks about the deck. The only unarmored man aboard is an old, ONE-LEGGED COOK, mending spears. Patroclus angrily strips off his breastplate and drops it to the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector and Tecton gallop through the gate. They rein in their horses and look over the elite Apollonian Guard, eighty of Troy's finest soldiers, riding well-groomed, snorting mounts. When Hector speaks his voice is clear and steady.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: All my life I've lived by a code, and the code is simple. (beat) Honor the gods. (beat) Love your woman. (beat) And defend your country. The men roar.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Troy is mother to us all. Fight for her! The men roar and thrust their spears into the air. Hector leads the charge to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles stands in his ship's bow, scanning the Trojan dunes. He turns to face his men. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Myrmidons, we are brothers of the sword. I'd rather fight alongside you than any army of thousands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4вЂќ 48 49 50 48. CONTINUED: 4вЂќ The Myrmidons cheer. Achilles points his sword toward Troy.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Do you know what's waiting beyond that beach? (beat) Immortality. The Myrmidons raise their swords and cry out with one voice. The oarsmen give one last mighty pull on their oars and beach the tar-caulked keel of the warship on Trojan sand. Achilles puts on his helmet, grabs a coiled rope anchored to a bronze cleat, and rappels down to the beach. The Myrmidons follow him, tossing the ropes off the deck and shimmying down to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The archers behind the fortifications watch the Myrmidons climb down from their ship. Their CAPTAIN raises his hand: wait... wait... CAPTAIN of archers Now! The archers rise and release their arrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of arrows whistle through the air. Four of the Myrmidons climbing down cry out as arrows hit them; they tumble into the sea. Other arrows rip into the packed sand or zip harmlessly into the water. The Myrmidons, clustered together and holding their shields above their heads, look to Achilles. Achilles makes a hand signal. Half his men split off and run to the fortifications on their left, howling like wolves as arrows rain down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patroclus huddles under the railing beside the cook as arrow after arrow screams by. A flaming arrow hits one of the sails, and then another. The sails begin to burn. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ONE-LEGGED COOK
dialogues.text: Help me get the sails down! The cook limps over to the sails, ignoring the arrows tha rain around him. Patroclus takes a deep breath and runs in a crouch to the cook. Together they lower the burning sails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles sprints toward the archers, half his men behind him. The archers let off another volley. More Myrmidons fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agamemnon, Menelaus, and Nestor watch the battle from the prow of their ship. They're still half a mile away.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: (in awe despite himself) The man wants to die. We hear SHOUTS of "Achilles!" from the other ships, a great clamor as men bash the flats of their swords agains their shields and cheer their hero on. Agamemnon hears the cheering. He grits his teeth and glares at the distant Achilles. Nestor notices Agamemnon's barely concealed fury. He speaks quietly, so no one else can hear.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: Give him his battle. You'll take the war.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Give him too many battles and the men will forget who's king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector and his men near the high dunes, galloping at breakneck speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles, three arrows in his shield, sprints across the sands. Arrows tear through the air about him. No man alive can run with Achilles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leaps over the fortification, sword flashing before hi feet ever touch the ground. The archers crumple to the ground as Achilles' sword cuts through them. In a moment the Myrmidons catch up to Achilles and lay into the archers. Within seconds they massacre them. Achilles turns and nods to the temple: the next target. Eudorus gasps for air. Achilles regards him with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Breathe, my friend. Eudorus takes two deep breaths. Achilles dashes for the temple. His Myrmidons follow behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The archers at the temple unleash a fusillade of arrows. Every few yards another Myrmidon falls. Several of them are wounded, but if they're not dead they keep moving forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajax's ship is one hundred yards from shore. Legendary AJAX (30) -- a huge man, brutally muscled, head shaved, face and body scarred -- stands in the prow, watching Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: AJAX
dialogues.text: Look at him, hogging all the glory. He walks over to his rowers, grabs an oarsmen on the fron bench under the armpits and tosses him away. Ajax sits, grabs the oar handle, and begins rowing maniacally, the veins in his massive arms bulging through the skin.

dialogues.speaker: AJAX
dialogues.text: Row, you lazy whores, row! Greeks are dying! The oarsmen redouble their efforts and the ship leaps ove the waves toward the shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector and the Apollonian Guards rein in their horses ato the dunes. Hector sees Ajax's ship plowing into the beach. Hundreds of other ships are close behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trojan archers rain arrows down on Ajax's ship. Several flaming arrows catch in the hull and begin to burn.

dialogues.speaker: TECTON
dialogues.text: We can't hold the beach, my prince. Hector sees where Achilles and the Myrmidons are heading.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: They're trying to take the temple.

dialogues.speaker: TECTON
dialogues.text: No believer would spill blood in Apollo's temple. Hector, increasingly uneasy, watches Achilles dodge arrows. He turns and points to the spot where Ajax's ship has landed.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: (to an Apollonian officer) The archers need help. Burn as many ships as you can, but don't sacrifice yourself. Bring the men back to the city. The OFFICER bows and leads 60 Guards to the fortifications.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: (to Tecton) Follow me. He gallops toward the temple, Tecton and his men behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles, his shield now quilled with arrows, hurls his spear. It catches the closest archer just above the breastplate, tearing through the man's throat. The archers near by throw down their bows and take up the spears racked behind them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But Achilles is already upon them, cutting them down with ruthless precision. Every time his bronze sword flashes through the air another Trojan falls, and Achilles keeps sweeping through them, his face painted with Trojan blood The other Myrmidons are fighting beside their leader now, and the Trojan archers are no match for the Myrmidons in hand to hand combat. Soon the temple area belongs to the Greeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajax and his men rappel down the ship's hull while arrows rip into wood and flesh. Ajax carries a giant battle-axe and a shield twice the size of most men's. When he reaches the surf he doesn't wait for his men; he roars and charges at the archers in the dunes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles, not even breathing hard after the slaughter, removes his helmet and rests it on the wall. The surviving Myrmidons search the grounds, dispatching any dying Trojans. Eudorus hurries over to Achilles' side.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: The temple is secure.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: The Sun God is the patron of Troy, our enemy. Take whatever treasure you can find. The Myrmidons cheer and rush the temple.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: With your permission, my lord --

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Speak. Eudorus gestures to the sun above them.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Apollo sees everything. Perhaps it's not wise to offend him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Achilles nods and walks over to the towering statue of Apollo in front of the temple. Eudorus watches in horror as Achilles climbs atop the statue and beheads Apollo with a swing of his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector and Tecton rein in their horses.

dialogues.speaker: TECTON
dialogues.text: He dares attack Apollo? Hector spurs his horse and races toward the invaders, followed by his twenty men. The other sixty Apollonians gallop to Ajax's landing spot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles gazes at the sky as if waiting for the sun to blast him for blasphemy. Nothing happens. Hearing hoofbeats, Achilles turns and spots Hector and hi men, two hundred yards away.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: (to Budorus) Get inside the temple, warn the men. Eudorus hurries to warn his comrades.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Eudorus! Wait, wait a moment. The Myrmidon captain stops. Achilles hefts a spear, judges the distance, and throws. One hundred yards from Achilles, the spearhead finds its mark: Tecton's breastplate. Tecton is knocked from his horse and skewered to the ground. He clutches at the wooden shaft, not comprehending his fate. Hector reins in his horse and stares at his fallen captain. The man is finished. Hector turns to look at Achilles. Eudorus's eyes are wide. No other man alive could have thrown a spear that far or that accurately. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Now you can go. Eudorus runs inside the temple. Hector kicks his horse and gallops toward Achilles. His men cry out and follow him. Achilles waits. Hector raises his own spear. When he is fifty yards away, he throws. At the very last moment, Achilles bends his head to one side, an almost lackadaisical movement. The spear rips through the air occupied by Achilles' head half a moment before. Achilles smiles. Hector draws his sword and charges, his men right behind him. Achilles walks, with insulting insouciance, into the temple. A series of high steps lead inside the temple. Hector and the Trojans dismount and proceed cautiously to the temple

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An arrow sticks out of Ajax's leg but he doesn't seem to notice it. He bulls forward, giant shield held in front, and slams into the Trojan ranks. Where Achilles is all grace and speed, Ajax is brute force. Parrying his blows is useless: his battle axe splits bronze shields, bronze swords, bronze helmets. The sound of his axe carving through a breastplate and th man beneath the breastplate is like nothing else on earth As Ajax drops another Trojan, he lifts his ax to the heavens.

dialogues.speaker: AJAX
dialogues.text: I am Ajax, breaker of stones, widow-maker of Salamis! Look upon me, Trojans, and despair! The Apollonians join the fight against the Greeks. The Guards are far better than the archers at hand-to-hand combat.  63 64 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector and his men enter the temple. Eyes adjusting to the gloomy light, they gingerly advance. All is quiet. Evidence of looting is everywhere. At the back of the temple, stairs lead up to the altar room. Hector walks toward the stairs. Blood trickles down the steps. Hector raises his eyes. Achilles stands atop the staircase, both hands wrapped around the hilt of his sword, the sword point resting on the top step. He stares down at Hector. WAR CRIES explode through the temple. The Myrmidons burst from their hiding places and rush the Trojans. Hector is an obvious target. Two Myrmidons charge him, their spears leveled. If Achilles is the apotheosis of martial grace, Hector is something altogether different -- a man of ordinary gifts who has become an extraordinary warrior by dint of experience, endless training, and powerful intelligence. As the Myrmidons charge he waits. At the last moment he swings his sword, slicing both spearheads from their shafts. The Myrmidons stare at their decapitated spears. Hector doesn't give them a chance to recover. He pounces, sword flashing, and both men fall to the temple floor. Achilles watches from the top step. Hector begins running up the stairs. Achilles disappears inside the altar room. Another Myrmidon bounds up the stairs after Hector. The prince wheels about and kicks the Myrmidon in the breastplate. The soldier tumbles down the steps. Hector continues up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As more Greek ships make landfall, the Apollonian officer sees that their position is no longer defensible.

dialogues.speaker: APOLLONIAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Back to the city! Back to the city! The Trojans begin to retreat. The archers still turn to fire whenever there's time. Mounted Guards haul fleeing archers onto their horses.  65 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector finds the bodies of two PRIESTS. They lie on the stone floor, limbs splayed, throats slit. Sitting atop the altar, half-hidden by the shadows, is Achilles. He's a terrible sight to behold, splattered with blood, his bronze sword still dripping.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You must be very brave or very stupid, to come after me alone. (beat) You must be Hector. Hector stares at Achilles a moment before kneeling by the dead priests' bodies.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: A private audience with the prince of Troy. I'm flattered. Do you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: These priests weren't armed. Hector closes the eyes of the murdered priests. Achilles jumps down from the altar and looks at the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I didn't kill them. Cutting old men's throats -- there's no honor in that.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Honor? (spits) Children and fools fight for honor. I fight for my country. Hector charges. Achilles dances back, staying just out of reach. Achilles looks relaxed, almost playful.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Fight me.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
