dialogues.text: Why kill you, prince of Troy, with no one here to see you fall? Achilles backs out of an archway opening onto the bright day outside. Hector follows.  66 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down at the beach, scores of Greek ships are on the sand.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Why did you come here? Achilles gestures at the invading flotilla.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: They'll be talking about this war for a thousand years.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: In a thousand years even the dust from our bones will be gone.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Yes, prince. But our names will remain. A band of bloodied Myrmidons, led by Eudorus, emerges fro the temple. Hector, surrounded by enemies, warily backs off.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: (to Achilles) The Trojans are dead.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Go home, prince. Drink some wine. Make love to your wife. Tomorrow we'll have our war.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You speak of war as if it's a game. But how many wives wait at Troy's gate for husbands they'll never see again?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Perhaps your brother can comfort them. I hear he's good at charming other men's wives. Hector stares at Achilles and the Myrmidons for another moment before walking away.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Why did you let him go?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: It's too early in the day for killing princes.  67 68 69 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousands of Greek soldiers on the beach watch as the Trojans retreat, many of the archers riding behind their Apollonian saviors. Hector mounts his horse and rides back toward the city. When the Greeks see Achilles climbing onto the temple's roof they stare in awe, silent. Achilles raises his bloodied bronze sword toward the sun. The CLAMOR that erupts from the beach is deafening. Thousands of men cheering and yelling his name: Achilles! Achilles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agamemnon, still aboard his ship, waits for the gangplank to be lowered. His dark eyes are cold and hateful as he listens to the men cheering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers tug more and more ships onto the sand. From the landed ships, primitive cranes are already beginning to lower boxes of provisions, military materiel, and horses. Achilles walks across the beach, carrying his helmet, accepting the congratulations of the troops. Ajax, shirtless, strides over.

dialogues.speaker: AJAX
dialogues.text: Achilles! Achilles halts. For a moment there seems to be tension in the air. Everyone watches. Ajax gives Achilles a bear hug.

dialogues.speaker: AJAX
dialogues.text: You're as fearless as a god.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: The gods are immortal. What do they have to fear? Ajax laughs and releases Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: AJAX
dialogues.text: I'm honored to go to war with you. Achilles nods and grips the big man's thick arm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I don't have to worry about my back with you behind me. Achilles continues walking. He sees Odysseus walking down a gangplank from his ship to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: (calling out) If you sailed any slower, the war would be over.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: I don't mind missing the beginning of the war -- as long as I'm here at the end. Achilles smiles and keeps walking. He arrives at the Myrmidon's newly established base. Patroclus, Eudorus, and the other surviving Myrmidons greet Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: We have something to show you. Achilles follows Eudorus and the grinning Myrmidons to a large tent twenty yards inland from their beached ship. A few Myrmidons hammer the last tent pegs deep into the sand. Eudorus holds open the tent flap. Achilles looks at his captain for a moment before entering the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No rugs have been laid down yet, so loot from the temple has been stacked on the sand: gold chalices, black amphorae, woven tapestries, goatskins filled with sacred wine. But Achilles does not look at this plunder. Bound by the wrists to the center pole of the tent is Briseis, dressed in her white robes. Terrified but trying to retain her composure, she returns Achilles' stare. Robes torn, hair disheveled, bleeding from the lip: she still possesses her innate dignity and strength. Something changes in Achilles' eyes when he looks at her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: The men found her hiding in the temple. They thought she'd.. please you.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Leave us. Eudorus bows and exits. Achilles pulls a small, sharp knife from his belt. Briseis stares at the blade. Achilles walks over to her and cuts the ropes that bind her. She sits back, rubbing the chafed skin of her wrists, still watching Achilles. He sheathes his knife.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: What's your name? Briseis stares at him but doesn't answer. Achilles becomes aware, for the first time, that he's covered in blood. He wipes a hand across his face. Briseis looks about the tent, as if searching for a way out.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You're safer in this tent than out there. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: You killed Apollo's priests.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I've killed men in five countries. But never a priest.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Then your men did. (beat) The Sun God will have his vengeance. Achilles removes his bronze grieves.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: What's he waiting for? Briseis is stunned by such blunt blasphemy but she can't take her eyes off him, because Achilles, after all, is Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: The right time to strike. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Achilles removes his breastplate.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: His priests are dead and his acolyte's a captive. (beat) I think your god is afraid of me. Briseis laughs bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Afraid? Apollo is master of the sun. He fears nothing. Achilles nods and looks around the dark tent.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Then where is he? Briseis has no answer. Achilles smiles and she looks away. A bucket of hot water sits beside a washcloth. Achilles wets the cloth and begins to scrub the blood from his body.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: You're nothing but a killer. You don't know anything about the gods.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You haven't seen twenty summers and you think you know my heart? I know more about the gods than priests could ever teach you. (beat) You're royalty, aren't you? Briseis says nothing. Achilles smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You've spent years talking down to men, you must be royalty. What's your name? (beat) Even the servants of Apollo have names.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Briseis. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Are you afraid, Briseis? Briseis is quiet for a moment. She watches Achilles with a mixture of fear and curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Should I be?

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (calling from outside the tent) My lord --

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: What is it? Eudorus sticks his head inside the tent.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: King Agamemnon requests your presence.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Why would I want to look at him when I can look at her?

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: All the kings are there, celebrating the victory. Achilles stands.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Give me a moment. Eudorus withdraws. A long beat while Achilles studies her.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You don't need to fear me, girl. You're the only Trojan who can say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two muscular GUARDS stand by the opening to Agamemnon's tent. Achilles, wearing clean clothes, doesn't bother waiting for the guards' permission to enter; he brushes past them and through the tent flap.  72 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The largest tent on the beach, Agamemnon's command quarters are a lush affair, decorated with the spoils of dozen wars. Several AIDES-DE-CAMP bustle in and out on various errands. The Greek kings are here: Odysseus, Ajax, Menelaus, etc. Agamemnon sits on a heavy wood throne, garishly inlaid with gold, mother-of-pearl, and precious stones. Triopas, king of Thessaly, kneels before Agamemnon.

dialogues.speaker: TRIOPAS
dialogues.text: You've won a great victory, King of Kings. No one thought the Trojan beach could be captured so easily. He hands Agamemnon a ceremonial dagger with a gold hilt.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: A beautiful gift, Triopas. You will be among the first to walk the streets of Troy tomorrow. Triopas stands and bows. Achilles has watched this exchange with disbelief. He glances at Odysseus, who shrugs. Now Nestor, king of the Pylians, kneels before Agamemnon and hands him an urn decorated with painted warriors.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: My father Neleus had this urn made to commemorate his victory at Cyparisseis. I present it to you in honor of an even more memorable victory.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Thank you, old friend. Tomorrow we'll eat supper in the gardens of Troy. Nestor stands and bows. Agamemnon places the dagger and urn beside a pile of other luxurious gifts. As the kings file out of the tent, Odysseus clasps Achilles' shoulder and speaks to him out of the others' earshot.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: War is young men dying and old men talking. You know this. Ignore the politics. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Odysseus exits the tent. Agamemnon deigns to notice Achilles waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: (to his aides) Leave us. The aides exit, leaving Achilles and Agamemnon alone. Achilles eyes the pile of gifts.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Apparently you've won some great victory.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Ah, perhaps you didn't notice. The Trojan beach belonged to Priam in the morning. It belongs to Agamemnon in the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You can have the beach. I didn't come here for sand.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: No, you came because you want your name to last through the ages. (beat) A great victory was won today -- but the victory is not yours. Kings did not kneel to Achilles. Kings did not bring homage to Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: The battle was won by soldiers. The soldiers know who fought.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: History remembers the kings, not the soldiers. (beat) Tomorrow we'll batter down the gates of Troy. I'll build monuments to victory on every island of Greece, and carve Agamemnon in the stone. My name will last forever. Your name is written in the sand, for the waves to wash away.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: First you need the victory. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Achilles turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: One more thing, son of Peleus. Achilles stops.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear my father's name from your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: The first pick of the battle's spoils always goes to the commander. Your men sacked the temple of Apollo, yes?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You want gold? Take it, it's my gift, to honor your courage. Take what you want.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I already have. Aphareus! Haemon! Two battle-scarred soldiers, APHAREUS and HAEMON, drag Briseis into the tent. Her face is bruised -- clearly she's been slapped around.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: The spoils of war. Tonight I'll have her give me a bath. And then -- who knows? Achilles draws his sword.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: (to the soldiers) I have no quarrel with you, brothers. But you'll never see home again if you don't let her go. The soldiers hesitate, then draw their own swords. Achilles advances on them.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Guards! The two sentries rush into the tent, swords drawn. Achilles is surrounded. He raises his sword. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Stop! Everyone stops and looks at the girl. Despite her torn robes, her noble bearing and authoritative tone command respect.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Too many people have died today. She looks at the various men in the room and finally addresses Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: If killing is your only talent, that's your curse. But I don't want anyone dying for me. Everyone is quiet until Agamemnon laughs.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Mighty Achilles, silenced by a slave girl.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: She's not a slave.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: She is now. Achilles' eyes are flat and merciless.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Before my time is done, King of Kings, I will look down on your corpse and smile. Achilles turns and leaves the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the ships have been hauled onto the beach. Hundreds of soldiers finish digging a long trench in the sand. Pikes are anchored and other fortifications constructed to protect the tents and ships from attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dying light, the Trojans prepare their city for siege. Gray-bearded OFFICERS oversee the reinforcement of the main gates. SOLDIERS haul thousands of arrows atop the city walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive CONGREGATION at the Temple of Zeus kneels befor the Thunder God's statue while PRIESTS burn the BODIES of fallen Trojan soldiers on tall PYRES. The WIDOWS keen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beach is lit by thousands of torches. The Greeks have transformed the serene beach into a well-fortified camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priam stands by the room's open archway. Beyond the city he sees his beach occupied by the tremendous Greek force. Hector, Paris, and several of Troy's leading GENERALS, ARISTOCRATS and PRIESTS sit around the long table. One of the generals, GLAUCUS (60), pounds the table with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: If they want a war, we'll give them awar. I'd match the best of Troy against the best of Greece any day. VELIOR (40), a big-bellied nobleman, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: VELIOR
dialogues.text: The best of Greece outnumber the best of Troy, two to one.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: So what do you suggest, we surrender the city, let the Greeks slaughter our men and rape our wives? Velior looks at Paris until the prince returns his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: VELIOR
dialogues.text: I suggest diplomacy. The Greeks came here for one thing. Let's be honest, my friends. Trojans are burning on the pyre right now because of one youthful indiscretion. Paris looks away from Velior. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Glaucus, you've fought with me for forty years. Can we win this war?

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Our walls have never been breached. Our archers are the best in the world. And we have Hector. His men would fight the shades of Tartarus if he commanded. We can win. ARCHEPTOLEMUS (65), High Priest of Troy, wearing a long white robe embroidered with gold thread, now raises his voice.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: I spoke with two farmers today. They saw an eagle flying with a serpent clutched in its talons. (beat) This is a sign from Apollo. We will win a great victory tomorrow. Troy is the eagle. The Greeks --

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Bird signs! You want to plan our strategy based on bird signs?

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Hector. Show respect. When Archeptolemus prophesied four years of drought, we dug deeper wells. The drought came and we had water to drink. The high priest is a servant of the gods.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: And I'm a servant of Troy. (beat) I've always honored the gods, father. You know that. But today I fought with a Greek who desecrated the statue of Apollo. Apollo didn't strike the man down. (beat) The gods won't fight this war for us. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: There won't be a war. (he stands) This is not a conflict of nations. It's a dispute between two men. And I don't want to see another Trojan die because of me.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Paris --

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning I will challenge Menelaus for the right to Helen. The winner will take her home. The loser will burn before nightfall. Paris leaves the room. The others sit in stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Does he have a chance? Everyone looks at Hector, who meditates before answering.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I want our army outside the gate in the morning. Agamemnon won't let this war end with a duel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priam's gardens are wondrous: palm trees grow in the courtyard; flowered vines climb the walls; Aeolian harps chime in the breeze. Priam and Paris sitting on a bench, facing a statue of Aphrodite. The king holds a cloth-wrapped bundle in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Father, I... I'm sorry for the pain I've caused you. I --

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Do you love her? Paris looks up at the statue of Aphrodite. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: You're a great king because you love your country so much. Every blade of grass, every grain of sand, every rock in the river -- you love all of Troy. (beat) That's the way I love Helen. Priam nods and contemplates the goddess of beauty.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: I've fought many wars in my time. Some were fought for land, some for power, some for glory. (beat) I suppose fighting for love makes more sense than all the rest. Paris says nothing, but his father's words seem to reliev a great burden from his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: But I won't be the one fighting. He hands Paris the bundle. Paris, curious, begins unwrapping the cloth. Finally the object is uncovered: a shining sword, expertly forged, inscribed with the seal o Troy.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: The Sword of Troy.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: My father carried this sword, and his father before him, all the way back to the founding of Troy. The history of our people was written with this sword. (beat) Carry it with you tomorrow. Paris holds the sword up and it glows in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: The spirit of Troy is in that sword. As long as a Trojan carries it, our people have a future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector sits on the bed beside Andromache, who nurses thei baby boy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hector looks exhausted. He stares at his son.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: He has no idea what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Thank the gods.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: The man who killed Tecton outside Apollo's temple -- I've never seen a spear thrown like that. An impossible throw. A long beat until Andromache breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Briseis was in Apollo's temple this morning. Hector stares at Andromache.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Are you sure? She nods, swallows hard, and closes her eyes. After a moment Hector, his eyes full of sorrow, runs his hand through her long hair.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I need to see my brother.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Don't go.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I need to speak with him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: I mean tomorrow. Don't go. You've fought enough. Let other men go out there.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You think I want to fight, my love? I want to see my son grow tall. I want to see the girls chasing after him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Just like they chased his father? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: He's much more handsome than I ever was. For a moment they sit quietly, watching their son.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: I lost seven brothers in the Spartan Wars. You'd think I'd be good at losing by now. (beat) I can't lose you. I won't survive. Hector stares at her for a beat before pulling her close and kissing her. Everything is in this kiss, their entire past. Andromache finally lets him go and Hector walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hector walks to Paris's room, he spies someone in a dark cloak sneaking down the candle-lit hallway -- an assassin?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Wait! The cloaked figure looks back and then runs. Hector chases. The fugitive runs through the archway at the end of the corridor and into the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector runs into the garden. He's far faster. He seizes his quarry and pulls aside the fugitive's cowl. It's Helen.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Helen? By the light of the moon he examines her face. The stress of recent weeks has taken its toll, but the shadows beneath her eyes make her face more compelling than ever. Embarrassed by the awkwardness of their position, Hector stands and helps Helen to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: What are you doing out -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Helen runs. Hector catches her again after a few strides.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Let me go.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Where? Helen struggles against Hector's grip, but it's useless.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Let me go! Helen, still struggling, begins to cry. Hector pulls her to his chest. She cries for real now, violently sobbing, her mouth muffled against Hector's body.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Shh. Shh.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I saw them burn. I saw them burning on the pyres. (beat) It's my fault.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: It is. You know it is. All those widows. I still hear them screaming. Helen takes a deep breath. She manages to control herself.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Their husbands died because I'm here. Hector can't deny this. Helen pushes herself out of his grip.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I'm going down to the ships.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: No. You're not. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I'll give myself back to Menelaus. He can do what he wants -- kill me, make me his slave. Anything's better than this.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: It's too late for that. You think Agamemnon cares about his brother's marriage? This is about power. Not love.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Paris is going to fight in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Menelaus will kill him. Hector looks away, the words hurting him.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I won't let that happen.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: It's his decision.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: No. No. I can't ask anyone to fight for me. I'm no longer queen of Sparta. Hector bows to Helen and kisses her hand.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You're a princess of Troy. And my brother needs you tonight. Helen stares at Hector in wonder. The words seem to bolster her spirit, and she smiles though her eyes are still wet. She nods, touches his arm and goes back to the palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up and down the beach thousands of GREEK WARRIORS prepare for battle. Despite their vast numbers, the men are oddly quiet, each absorbed with his own thoughts. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON SEVERAL FACES -- these are men we haven't seen before and probably won't see again, not kings or heroes but ordinary men preparing for battle. One warrior prays with eyes closed, mumbling the words, kneeling in the sand. A second man inspects each arrowhead in his quiver. A third sits in the sand, snapping seashells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles sits cross-legged, arms held straight out in front of him, palms up. His bronze sword is balanced on his palms. Patroclus and Eudorus, armored for battle, enter the tent Achilles does not look away from his blade. Though the sword must be heavy, his arms do not tremble.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: My lord? The army is marching.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Let them march. We stay.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: But the men -- Achilles turns to glare at him and Eudorus falters.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: -- the men are ready.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Agamemnon spat on my honor yesterday. I promised that girl her safety and he stole her from me. Let him fight the Trojans today. Eudorus and Patroclus exchange glances. Eudorus bows to Achilles and exits the tent. Patroclus remains behind.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: When I was very small I saw my father kill a man with his bare hands. Patroclus doesn't know how to respond to this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: There's so much blood in a human body. Achilles flips the sword in the air and catches it by the hilt. He examines the edge.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You're ready to fight, Patroclus?

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: I am. Achilles rests his sword on the ground. He stares at Patroclus for a moment before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You're ready to kill? Patroclus hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: At night I see their faces. All the men I've killed. I see them standing on the far bank of the River Styx. (beat) They're waiting for me. Patroclus stands absolutely still. He's never heard his cousin speak this way before.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Some nights I walk among them. When I wake I can still hear their words. (beat) They say, "Welcome, brother." Achilles inspects the knuckles of his fist.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Never hate the men you fight. All of us are mortals. All of us wretched things, tumbled crying from our mother's loins. (beat) Only the gods are free from sorrows.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: I hate no one, cousin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Good. (beat) I taught you how to fight. But I never taught you why to fight.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: I fight for you.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: And who will you follow when I'm gone? Patroclus hesitates, unsure how to answer.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Most soldiers battle for kings they've never met. They do what they're told; they die when they're told to die.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: Soldiers obey.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: We don't have much time to walk in the sun, Patroclus. After this life comes the underworld, an eternity telling stories to other shades. Don't tell them you died following some fool's orders.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: And what should I tell them?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Tell them your name. If your life has been worthy, they'll know the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thousand ARCHERS stand in various positions on the broad city walls, quivers of arrows by their sides. TROJAN CITIZENS also crowd atop the walls, quiet and sober. Priam sits in a grandstand beneath a blue canopy. Seated by him are CITY LEADERS, including Velius and Archeptolemus. Helen stands apart from everyone else. No one is overtly hostile to her, but behind her back people stare and whisper.  84

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below the walls, on the broad field that stretches down from the city gates, the TROJAN ARMY has amassed. In the front, Hector and General Glaucus sit astride their horses. The soldiers are disciplined and well-outfitted, arranged in tight formation. Paris rides out to join Hector. Hector examines Paris's face.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Are you sure you want to do this?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I started this war. Paris searches the faces atop the city wall. He finds Helen. CLOSE on Helen. The wind is blowing hard, ruffling her cloak, her hair. There is love in her eyes, and fear and exhaustion. Paris stares up at her for a long time before turning away. A low, ominous RUMBLE grows steadily louder. Hector hears it first. He looks down the vast sloping field toward the sea. Now the other soldiers hear it, and then the citizens ato the walls. All speech ceases. The Trojans quietly wait. The rumbling resolves into the steady beat of WAR DRUMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now we see them, fifty thousand GREEKS. The reflection of sunlight off fifty thousand bronze shields, fifty thousand bronze helmets and chest plates, is spectacular -- the army looks like a river of lava, flowing uphill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trojan soldiers don't quiver or waver, but the expressions on their faces betray their anxiety. The Greek army is more than twice the size of the Trojan army  85 86 87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The citizens shield their eyes from the brightness. They exhibit their nervousness more openly than the soldiers. One OLD WOMAN moans softly, her hand over her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patroclus, Eudorus, and the rest of the Myrmidons climb t the top of a tall bluff near the beach. From here they can see the broad battlefield a mile away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greek army halts just beyond arrow range. A delegation of kings -- Agamemnon, Nestor, Menelaus, Odysseus, and Ajax -- on CHARIOTS proceeds to the center of the battlefield. Odysseus looks over his shoulder and then yells to Ajax.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Where's Achilles? Ajax looks around and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector and Paris spur their horses and canter out to meet the Greeks. The brothers speak without looking at each other.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Menelaus is a bull. He'll charge you. Paris nods.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: He's stronger than you, so try not to fight him up close. Keep your distance. Use your quickness. Paris leans over and tries to spit, but his mouth is too dry.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Brother? Paris, his face ashen, looks at Hector.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You don't have to do this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Paris shakes his head and continues riding toward Menelaus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, alone, views the battlefield. An old, spotted hand takes her elbow. She turns and looks into Priam's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Sit with me. Helen follows the king to his grandstand and sits beside him. She's aware of people staring at them but he seems oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: All my life I've prayed against this day.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Yes, my king.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Call me father, dear child. Startled by this affection, she hesitates before responding.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Forgive me, father. For... She pauses, staring out at the vast Greek army.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: ...bringing this. Priam shakes his head and smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: I blame you for nothing. Everything is in the hands of the gods. (beat) Besides, how could I blame anyone for falling in love with Paris? Helen looks out at the battlefield, fixing on Paris, at this distance a tiny figure on horseback. Priam takes her hand.  89 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector and Paris ride up to the Greek kings. Menelaus stares at Paris, his fingers tapping the hilt of his sword. Paris does not make eye contact. The kings step down from their chariots and the Trojan princes dismount from their horses. Both armies are lined up several hundred yards apart. Agamemnon surveys the Trojan army.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I see you're not hiding behind your high walls. Valiant of you. I1l- advised, but valiant.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You come here uninvited. Go back to your ships. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: We've come too far, Prince Hector.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Prince? These are not princes. What son of a king would accept a man's hospitality, eat his food, drink his wine, and then steal his wife in the middle of the night?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: The sun was shining when your wife left you. Menelaus draws his sword. He points it at the city walls.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: She's up there watching, isn't she? Good. I want her to watch you die. Agamemnon places a hand on his brother's arm.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Not yet, brother. He makes a sweeping gesture, indicating his entire army.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Look around you, Hector. I've brought all the warriors of Greece to your shores. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: You can still save Troy, young prince.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I have two wishes. If you grant them, no more of your people need to die. First, give Helen back to my brother. Second, Troy must submit to my command, to fight for me whenever I call.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You want me to look upon your army and tremble. Well, I see them. I see fifty thousand men brought here to fight for one man's greed.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Be careful, boy. My mercy has limits.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I've seen the limits of your mercy. And I tell you now that no son of Troy will ever submit to a foreign ruler.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Then every son of Troy shall die.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: There is another way. Everyone watches Paris now.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: (to Menelaus) I love Helen. I won't give her up. And neither will you. So let's fight our own battle. Let the winner take Helen home, and that will be the end of it.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: A brave offer. But not enough. Menelaus pulls Agamemnon aside and speaks to him out of the others' earshot.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Let me kill this little peacock. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I didn't come here for your pretty wife. I came for Troy.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: And I came for my honor. His every breath insults me. (beat) Let me kill him. When he's lying in the dust, give the signal to attack. I'll have my revenge and you'll have your city. Agamemnon ponders the offer. He nods. They rejoin the others.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: (to Paris) I accept your challenge. And tonight I'll drink to your bones. He walks over to his chariot and grabs his shield. Hector helps Paris into his helmet and speaks quietly to him.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: He doesn't have the stamina he once did. Make him swing and miss. He'll tire. Paris nods. He turns toward Menelaus but quickly turns back and grabs Hector's arm.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Hector! Hector waits. Paris opens his mouth but no words come out. He tries again.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: If I fall -- tell Helen -- tell her --

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Don't let Menelaus hurt her. Make him swear --

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Think about your sword and his sword. Nothing else. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hector hugs him close for a moment and releases him. Paris walks toward the center of the field, where Menelau waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's difficult to see from inside your bronze helmet. Your peripheral vision is severely restricted, and the nose guard bisects your vision. Your breathing sounds amplified, impossibly loud and half panicked. But there's no turning back. Menelaus stands in the center of the vast battlefield, patient and menacing, carving the air with lazy strokes of his sword. You look back and see Hector. Hector nods, trying to encourage you, but he looks worried. Behind Hector is the Trojan army, twenty-five thousand silent men. Behind the army is the city of Troy. Atop those walls, beneath that blue canopy, your father is watching, and th woman you love. You turn back to Menelaus. He's smiling at you.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 89B
dialogues.text: Menelaus charges at Paris and swings mightily, trying to knock the prince's head from his shoulders. Paris manages to duck beneath the flashing blade. Menelaus fights with little art and great savagery, exploiting his superior strength. Paris is quicker. He nearly surprises the bigger man with a fast sword thrust, but Menelaus dominates the fight, hammering Paris's shiel with a furious barrage of blows. Paris steps away and tries another thrust, but this time Menelaus sidesteps and smashes Paris in the jaw with the hilt of his sword, knocking the prince's helmet off. Paris falls, blood leaking from his nose and mouth. Hector, frustrated and powerless to help, tries to will his brother to victory.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Get up. Get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajax and Odysseus, standing together, watch the bloodied prince. Ajax looks disgusted, Odysseus amused.

dialogues.speaker: AJAX
dialogues.text: This is the prince of Troy? In Salamis, the women fight better.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: But they're not as pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, unable to sit, now stands at the wall, watching he lover battle her husband. Priam stands beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patroclus and the other Myrmidons watch the battle.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Menelaus still knows how to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menelaus swings at the fallen prince but Paris is able to block the blow with his shield and scramble to his feet. Menelaus points to the sky. Three CROWS circle above.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: You see the crows? (beat) They've never tasted a prince before. The Spartan's mind games are working -- Paris wears the face of a man who doesn't want to fight. He swings clumsily and Menelaus manages to catch his wrist. The Spartan grins and raises his sword for the kill. Paris lashes out with his free hand, punching the Spartan hard in the jaw. Menelaus grunts and shoves the Trojan away. He spits out a tooth. He's no longer smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS AND AJAX 92A
dialogues.text: exchange a quick glance: not bad.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS 92B
dialogues.text: But Menelaus bores in again, blow after blow. Finally his bronze blade bites into Paris's thigh. Paris staggers backward, blood flowing down his leg. He swings desperately but Menelaus parries, knocking the sword from Paris's hand. Paris stares at his fallen sword, five feet away. Paris runs. Menelaus snarls and chases after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The citizens seem shocked that their prince and hero woul flee before a Greek assailant. They look at each other and whisper, glancing at Priam, curious to see his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: (to himself) Fight him, son. Fight him. Helen stares at the battlefield, her face unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris runs to Hector, gasping for breath, the blood pouring down his face and leg. He falls to his knees before his older brother. Hector stares at Paris and then at Menelaus, who has stopped seven feet from the princes.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: Fight me, you coward! Fight me! Paris, unable to look at either man or speak, trembles by his brother's side. Hector, completely at a loss, lays his hand on Paris's head.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: We have a pact. Fight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGAMEMNON signals for the DRIVER of his chariot.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: The Trojans have violated the agreement. We march. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The driver nods. Agamemnon hops onto the chariot and they ride toward the army to deliver the orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HECTOR looks from his brother to the enraged Menelaus.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: This is not honor. This is not worthy of royalty. Hector looks at his brother but Paris is not looking at anybody. He gasps for breath, the blood streaming from his wounds. Hector glances at the Greek army, then back to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: If he doesn't fight, Troy is doomed.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Paris. Paris shakes his head, blood dripping from his nose.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: No. No.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: (to Menelaus) The fight is over.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: The fight is not over. Stand back, Prince Hector. Hector stares at the king, judging his intentions.

dialogues.speaker: MENELAUS
dialogues.text: I'll kill him at your feet. I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: He's my brother. Menelaus charges, sword raised overhead. In one motion Hector draws his own sword and plunges the point through Menelaus's breastplate. Menelaus's momentum carries him forward, until his breastplate touches the hilt of Hector's sword. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Menelaus, eyes wide open, stares down at the blood which now begins rushing down his armor. He looks up at Hector. Hector pulls his blade out. Menelaus falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGAMEMNON standing on his chariot in front of his army, sees his brother fall. For a moment the vast field is silent. Agamemnon SHOUTS. A wordless cry of rage, echoing from the Greek lines to the walls of Troy. He points toward Hector. The entire Greek army surges forward. Hollering with a collective violence powerful enough to make the ground tremble, fifty thousand soldiers charge at Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sees them coming. The ground he stands on trembles with the concussive force of Greek feet and horses' hooves.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Paris. Paris still seems to be in a state of shock.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Get up. Get up! The avalanche of Greek infantry is getting closer. Paris finally gets to his feet but runs in the wrong direction, toward the Greeks.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Paris! What seems to be a sprint to suicide turns out to be something different: Paris grabs the fallen sword of Troy from the ground, dangerously close to the charging Greeks He turns and dashes back to Hector. The princes mount. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Greeks are almost upon them. Brandishing their spears and screaming their war cries, all of them vie for the glory of felling the Trojan princes. The closest Greeks launch their spears. One whistles by Hector's ear. He spurs his horse. The princes gallop toward the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ODYSSEUS watches this chase with trepidation.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Our men are too close to the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GLAUCUS the Trojan general, sees that the princes have gained some distance from their pursuers. He calls to an OFFICER standing on the city wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patroclus turns and sees Achilles, standing on a high roc behind the other Myrmidons. We don't know how long Achilles has been watching the battle.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Pull back, you fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greek army continues to charge at full speed. One thousand TROJAN ARCHERS notch their arrows and pull back their catgut strings.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Now! One thousand bronze-tipped arrows soar into the air, a deadly swarm of hornets that rises toward the clouds before descending on the charging Greeks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hundreds of Greeks fall. The Trojan archers let loose another swarm of arrows. The arrows fall with a great HISS. Many find their mark, biting into the throats and faces of the Greeks. The Greek army, so overwhelming seconds ago, is now struc with chaos. The men in the front turn back, realizing they've become targets, while the men in back still push forward. In this confusion of foot traffic the arrows continue to fall, a rainstorm of bronze. Agamemnon, standing on his chariot in the middle of his frenzied troops, tries to maintain order, but his shouts go unheard above the general roar. The driver of his chariot falls, an arrow through his neck. Agamemnon grabs the reins and tries to steer the chariot, but so many men are running about, so many bodies litter the ground, that maneuvering is extremely difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HECTOR AND PARIS have reached the city walls, where Glaucus and the army wait for them. Hector grabs Paris's arm.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Get inside the city. He slaps Paris's horse. Paris, head bowed, rides away. Hector turns to his army. He shouts to them at the top of his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: The commander of the Greeks wants the Trojan army to fight for him! The Trojan mood becomes more and more bellicose.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Would any man here like to fight for Agamemnon?

dialogues.speaker: TROJANS
dialogues.text: No! Hector raises his sword and points it at the Greeks, who retreat from the arrow fusillade in disarray. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: For Troy!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: The Trojans charge. Hector, on horseback, reaches the Greeks first. His sword cuts down everyone within reach. The Trojan infantry attacks the Greeks, whose line has been broken by the rain of arrows. The Trojans take advantage of their enemies' panic. Hector's plan has succeeded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles is unable to stand still. His fingers twitch as he watches the battle; he paces back and forth and curses Patroclus and the Myrmidons avoid looking at their leader

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Get them in line... get them in line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odysseus, meanwhile, works to reorganize the troops.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Selepius! Bring your men back into line! Ajax, standing nearby, sees Hector chopping his way through the Greeks. Ajax runs at Hector. Two TROJAN SOLDIERS try to intercept Ajax. The mighty Greek swings his huge battle axe. The blade cuts clean through the first soldier's arm and halfway through his torso. The second soldier hacks at Ajax but the big man blocks the sword with his shield and then uses the shield to ram the soldier's face. Blood sprays from the Trojan's crushed skull. Both soldiers fall dead to the ground. Hector, battling a Greek INFANTRYMAN, doesn't see Ajax coming. Ajax grabs Hector's horse's bridle and tugs hard, the veins in his arms bulging beneath the skin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The horse tries to buck but Ajax twists the horse's head till it falls. Hector falls with the horse, tumbling to the dirt. The Greek infantryman he had been fighting stabs at him. Hector rolls away and manages -- while flat on his back -- to swing his sword, chopping off the infantryman's fee just above the ankles. The infantryman screams and falls. Ajax releases the horse, raises his axe, and swings at th fallen Hector. The prince gets his shield up just in time. Ajax's axe cleaves through the shield, splitting the bronze into two even halves. Hector stares at the halved shield, discards it, and jump to his feet. The two fighters circle each other while thousands of soldiers around them battle to the death.

dialogues.speaker: AJAX
dialogues.text: So you're the best of the Trojans? Hector, looking for an opening in the brute's defenses, says nothing. Ajax charges, swinging his battle axe. Hector ducks below the axe and lunges forward with his sword, but Ajax -- quick despite his size -- sidesteps, grabs the smaller man in a bear hug and squeezes. Hector turns red. The sword falls from Hector's hand. Ajax grins. Hector slams his helmeted head forward, butting Ajax in the face. Ajax staggers back, blood spraying from his nose, his axe falling to the ground. Hector struggles to regain his equilibrium. Ajax growls and launches himself at the prince. Hector snatches a spear off the ground and positions it just as Ajax dives at him. The spear pierces Ajax's armor, driving through his belly and out his back. Hector holds the shaft steady. Ajax stares down at his wound. He seems more irritated than anything else. Ajax places his two big hands on the spear shaft, right where the spear enters his body. He breaks the spear in two, snapping the solid wood like a twig. Half a spear still sticking out his back, Ajax swings the shaft, clobbering Hector in the side of the head, sending the horsehair-plumed helmet flying. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hector, dazed, falls to one knee. Ajax whacks him again on the back of his neck. Hector crawls forward blindly. His hands brush over the blade of his dropped sword. Hector springs up, driving his sword into Ajax's gut, jus below the big man's breast plate. Hector withdraws his sword. Both men see the ground drenched with Ajax's blood. Ajax backhands Hector with the broken spear shaft, cracking the prince in the jaw and dropping him again. Ajax grabs Hector, hoists him upright and begins throttling the prince. Ajax spits a great wad of blood and smiles, teeth washed red. Hector tries to kick at Ajax, but Ajax's thumbs dig deepe and deeper into Hector's throat. Hector's eyelids begin to flutter as he chokes. But the Salamisian king has lost too much blood. He sinks slowly to his knees. Hector is forced to his knees as well. Finally Ajax's eyes roll back. He topples onto Hector, hands still locked on the prince's throat. Hector undoes the death grip. He squirms out from under Ajax's corpse and stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patroclus and the Myrmidons watch Ajax fall with disbelief. Achilles cannot bear to watch any longer. He walks away. None of his men dare look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trojans are routing the Greeks. With two of their kings already fallen, the Greek force is in disarray. Odysseus sees Agamemnon speeding by on his chariot. Odysseus runs and manages to leap onto the chariot. The two kings shout at each other above the commotion of battle.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: We need to retreat! Agamemnon surveys the battlefield and his battered forces (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: My army has never lost a battle.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: If we don't fall back you won't have an army! Agamemnon seems dazed by the turn of events. Finally Odysseus hollers to whichever CAPTAINS can hear his voice

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Back to the ships! Back to the ships! The captains take up this cry, shouting orders to their men. The Greeks retreat. The Trojan soldiers give a mighty shout as they pursue their enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people cheer. Nobles and commoners embrace as brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector, still on foot, leads his men as they chase down the fleeing Greeks. Several thousand Greeks have fallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greeks get back to their trenches, the bulk of the force still intact. ARCHERS in the Greek rear guard, manning the trenches, now raise their bows and prepare to fire. Hector, eager to avoid the mistakes his Greek counterpart made earlier, holds up his hands and BELLOWS to the troops.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Halt! The Trojan army stops just outside the Greek archers! range. Lysander, the Trojan captain, stands beside Hector. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LYSANDER
dialogues.text: We have them on the run, my prince.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: We're almost in range of their archers. You saw what our arrows did to them. (beat) Have the men gather our fallen. When they're done, send an emissary to the Greeks. They can collect their dead without fear of assault.

dialogues.speaker: LYSANDER
dialogues.text: Would they have done the same for us?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Of course not. That's why Troy is worth defending. Hector turns and heads back to the white city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousands of BODIES litter the broad field. We see them first from high above, their bronze armor gleaming in the failing sunlight. CLOSE on several of the dead men's faces. The living haul the dead from the battlefield. HORSES are used to pull wagonloads of bodies. Fathers or sons or brothers or friends say their goodbyes and wash the dead men with washcloths and buckets of water. The sun sinks into the ocean. Both sides build funeral pyres for their fallen. When a body is loaded onto the pyre, a relative or friend places two COINS on the dead man's eyes. Dozens of SALAMISIANS view Ajax's body. They weep as they pass by, each man kneeling to kiss their fallen king's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agamemnon stands before the body of Menelaus. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He places two coins on Menelaus's eyes. He steps down from the pyre, accepts a torch from a CAPTAIN, and sets the pyre on fire.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I will burn their city before I leave, brother. I promise you that. As the sky grows dark, the dead burn on the beach and inside the walls of Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris flinches as Helen, using needle and thread, stitche his leg wound. His face is bruised, his eyes red.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: You think I'm a coward. Helen, concentrating on her stitching, says nothing. Paris flinches as the needle pierces his skin.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I am a coward. (beat) I knew he would kill me. I knew it. You were watching, and my father, my brother, all of Troy -- it didn't matter. The shame didn't matter. (beat) I gave up my pride, my honor. Just to live.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You challenged a great warrior. That took courage.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I betrayed you. Helen inspects her work. The black stitches are a little ragged, but they seem secure.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Menelaus was brave. He lived for fighting. And I hated him from the day I married him until the day he died. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Helen leans forward until her lips are inches from Paris.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I don't want a hero, my love. I want a man to grow old with. She kisses him and there is great tenderness in her kiss. A knock on the door. Helen looks up. Another knock.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Come in. Hector enters the room. He examines Paris's leg.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: (to Helen) Well stitched. (to Paris) You have a talented woman. (beat) I thank the gods you're alive, little brother.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I wanted to make you proud of me. He grips Paris' shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousands of campfires constellate the beach. Tens of thousands of exhausted soldiers stare into the flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nestor sits at a table, poring over the map of Troy. Odysseus lies in a hammock strung between two of the tent poles, eating olives and spitting out the pits. Agamemnon paces the rugs that floor the tent. His usual air of supreme confidence is gone, replaced by agitation.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: They're laughing at me in Troy. Old Priam and the others, drunk on victory. They think I'll quit these shores, sail home at first light. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Agamemnon 98. 107

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Maybe we should. spins and glares at Odysseus.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Flee like a whipped dog?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: The men believe we came here for Menelaus's wife. He won't be needing his wife anymore.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: (furious) My brother's blood still wets the grass and you insult him?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: It's no insult to say a dead man is dead.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: If we leave now we lose all eredibility. If the Trojans can beat us so easily, how long before the Hittites invade?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: You're right. But if we stay, we stay for the right reasons. (to Agamemnon) We stay to protect Greece, not your pride. Your private battle with Achilles is destroying us.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Achilles is one man. What good could he --

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Hector is one man. Look what he did to us today.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Hector fights for his country. Achilles fights only for himself.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: I don't care about the man's patriotism. I care about his ability to win battles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: (to Agamemnon) He's right. The men's morale is weak.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Weak? They're ready to swim home.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Even if I wanted to make peace with Achilles, the man won't listen. He's just as likely to spear me as speak with me.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: I'll talk to him in the morning. Agamemnon thinks about it for a moment and nods.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: He'll want the girl back.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: He can take the damned girl. I haven't touched her.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I gave her to the men. They needed some amusement after today. Odysseus and Nestor exchange worried looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A band of battle-weary, drunken SOLDIERS stand by a campfire. They're exhausted, caked with dirt and their comrades! blood. They shove Briseis back and forth between them. Each man she bounces into tears off a strip of her robes, which ar now filthy rags barely covering her body. Her face seems to have shut down. She has a bruise below one eye and her hair is wet with wine. The soldiers stare at her with a mix of hostility and lust.

dialogues.speaker: APHAEREUS
dialogues.text: You Trojan whore. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ECHEPOLUS
dialogues.text: We should kill her now, keep her from breeding any more Trojan bastards.

dialogues.speaker: APHAEREUS
dialogues.text: No, she's Agamemnon's property. (tearing off a sleeve) What's this? A virgin's robe?

dialogues.speaker: HAEMON
dialogues.text: You won't be needing that much longer. Haemon squats by the fire, holding an iron in the flames. He pulls out a branding iron in the shape of Agamemnon's seal: a white-hot ALPHA. He carries it toward Briseis.

dialogues.speaker: HAEMON
dialogues.text: Hold her down. Briseis sees the hot iron and begins to struggle, screaming and kicking at the men. Four of the soldiers pin her down.

dialogues.speaker: HAEMON
dialogues.text: Why are you kicking, girl? Better to be a Spartan slave than a Trojan priestess. Briseis claws Haemon in the face. He growls and punches her.

dialogues.speaker: HAEMON
dialogues.text: Come on, come on, hold her down. The soldiers hold her in the sand. Haemon steadies the hot brand and searches for the best place to mark her. When the brand is inches from her arm someone grabs the iron, pulls it out of Haemon's hands and then slams it down on the man's head. Haemon collapses. Achilles stands alone, unarmed save for the branding iron By firelight he looks ferocious. Echepolus stumbles backward.

dialogues.speaker: ECHEPOLUS
dialogues.text: Achilles. Aphaereus spits in the sand. He draws his sword. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: APHAREUS
dialogues.text: There's one of him and ten of us. Achilles swings the iron, almost too fast for the eye to follow. Aphaereus's face collapses. He falls to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Nine. The other soldiers run. Achilles lifts Briseis to her feet. More gently than we would have believed possible, Achilles brushes the sand from her face and hair.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Can you walk? Briseis nods. Achilles, arm around her shoulder, leads her away from the campfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eudorus and Patroclus are waiting when Achilles and Briseis get to the tent.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Get me food and water. And a new robe. Eudorus bows. Patroclus watches Achilles and Briseis enter the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles sits near Briseis, watching her. She's clean now, dressed in a new robe -- a man's robe, far too big for her. Platters of fruit and roasted meats sit near her, along with pitchers of wine and water. Briseis doesn't touch any of it.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You should eat. Briseis says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Did they hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: What do you think? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I saw you fight them. You have courage.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: To fight back when people attack me? A dog has that kind of courage.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I like dogs more than people. Briseis stares into Achilles' eyes. He's not used to people meeting his gaze. He stares back at the girl, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Why did you choose this life?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: What life?

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: This... to be a great warrior.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I chose nothing. I was born and this is what I am.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: But you must enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Does the scorpion feel joy when he stings the beetle? (beat) I doubt it. I doubt he feels anything at all.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: But you're not a scorpion. You're @ man.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: And you're a woman in love with a god. Where was Apollo when those men tried to scar you?

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Do you enjoy provoking me?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They watch each other, Achilles smiling, Briseis angry.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You've dedicated your life to the gods, yes? Briseis, glaring at him, doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Zeus, God of Thunder. Athena, Goddess of Wisdom. You serve them?

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: And Aries, God of War, who blankets his bed with the skins of men he's killed? Briseis pauses, caught in the trap.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: All the gods are to be feared and respected. For a long beat they are silent, staring at each other. The air between them is charged with more than mere contention.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: What do you want here in Troy? You didn't come for the Spartan queen.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I want what all men want. I just want it more. Achilles takes an apple and unsheathes a dagger. He tosses the apple in his hand. On the third toss he whips his knife-hand up and across and neatly catches four appl quarters. He offers a quarter to Briseis. Stunned, she slowly shakes her head. Achilles shrugs and eats the sliced apple. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I'll tell you a secret-- something they didn't teach you in your temple. The gods envy us. They envy us because we're mortal, because every moment might be our last. Everything is more beautiful for the doomed. He stares at her with such intensity she must look away.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You will never be lovelier than you are right now. And we will never be here again. Briseis is quiet for a moment. She rubs the ripe purple grapes on the platter beside her.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: I thought you were a dumb brute. She looks into Achilles' eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: I could have forgiven a dumb brute. EXT. BEACH - NIGHT lil It's quiet now. Only a few campfires burn under a full moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles lies on his back on a deer skin, sleeping. Briseis kneels beside him. In the candlelight we see the glint of a bronze blade. She holds the knife near his throat. Achilles open his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Go on. Briseis holds the blade against his skin.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Nothing is easier.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Aren't you afraid? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Every mortal dies. Today or fifty years from now, what does it matter in the face of eternity?

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: You'll kill more men if I don't kill you.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Many of them. For several seconds she holds the knife to his throat. Finally she puts it down.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: May Apollo forgive me. Achilles pulls her closer and they kiss. He slowly slides the robe off her shoulders. Briseis -- eyes closed, lips parted -- trembles as Achilles unveils her. For a moment she hesitates but soon hesitation evaporates and she presses her body against his, kissing his throat, his chest, his hands. Their hunger for each other is stronger than gods and nations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosy-fingered dawn appears. The seagulls cry above the waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles watches Briseis sleep. She looks very young and fragile, her face bruised, her eyelids fluttering as she dreams. Achilles watches her with great tenderness. Eudorus opens the tent flap. Sunlight streams in. Achilles puts a finger over his mouth. Eudorus sees Briseis and nods. Achilles gently pulls the blanket over her naked shoulders. He stands and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odysseus waits for Achilles outside the tent. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: (to Budorus) Have the men start loading the ship. We're going home. Eudorus, surprised, looks at Odysseus for a second before bowing to his commander and walking away.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: You found the girl?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I found her.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Is she hurt?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Not as badly as those who hurt her. Achilles stares at the sea. Seagulls patrol the skies.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Do you miss your wife, Odysseus?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Always.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I've never missed anyone in my life. I used to think it was a weakness, needing someone else.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: We all need someone else. Right now, Greece needs you.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Greece got along fine before I was born and Greece will be Greece long after I'm dead.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about the land. The valleys, the mountains -- they don't care what we do. The men need you. You should have seen the slaughter yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I saw it. And I saw who led the men to slaughter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Agamemnon... is a proud man. But he knows when he's made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: The man sends you to make his apologies? He doesn't understand honor. What are you doing in thrall to that pig of a king?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: The world seems simple to you, my friend. But when you're a king, very few choices are simple. Ithaca cannot afford an enemy like Agamemnon.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to fear him?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: You don't fear anyone, that's your problem. Fear is useful. (beat) Stay, Achilles. You were born for this war.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: My life is war. Is that what you think?

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Am I wrong? Achilles stares at the sea again.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: A week ago you were right. But things are less simple today.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Women have a way of complicating things. Achilles smiles. He turns to Odysseus and clasps his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Of all the kings of Greece, I respect you most. But in this war you're a servant. And I refuse to be a servant any longer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Sometimes you need to serve in order to lead. I hope you understand that one day. Odysseus walks away. Achilles watches him go and then turns back toward his tent. He sees that Patroclus has been standing by the tent throughout the previous conversation.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: We're going home?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: We leave at noon. He tries to enter his tent but Patroclus grabs his arm an blocks his path. Achilles stares at Patroclus' hand. Patroclus releases him but doesn't move out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: If Poseidon curses us and our ship goes down, what will I tell the shades in Hades? That I died running from this war, abandoning our countrymen?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Our countrymen?

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: Yes, our country! We're Greek, cousin. I broke bread with these men, I drank their wine, I listened to their jokes. These are our comrades. We cannot desert them. (beat) Your feud with Agamemnon is tearing this army apart. And your reputation suffers. The men are talking -- Achilles' eyes narrow as his temper rises.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: If my blood wasn't in your veins --

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: But your blood is in my veins. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I gave you an order, cousin. We leave at noon. Achilles opens the tent flap.

dialogues.speaker: PATROCLUS
dialogues.text: If you command us not to fight for the king of kings, so be it. But please don't ask me not to fight for Greece. (long beat) When the shades hear my name I want them to know I led a worthy life. Achilles, face inscrutable, watches his cousin walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The notables we've seen in this room before -- Priam, Hector, Glaucus, Velior, Archeptolemus -- are gathered again.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: The omens are gathering. The directive is clear.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Fight for your country. That's the only directive.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: (to Hector) The last time the high priest spoke to us he prophesied a great victory for Troy. We won a great victory. Let him speak. (to Archeptolemus) What course of action do you recommend?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: The gods favor our cause. Now is the time to destroy the Greek army.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Glaucus? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Their morale is battered. Hit them now, hit them hard, and they will run.

dialogues.speaker: VELIOR
dialogues.text: I must admit, I overestimated the Greeks. They lack discipline and courage. Hector, frustrated and weary, rubs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: The Myrmidons did not fight yesterday. There must be dissension among the Greeks. But if we attack their ships, we'll unify them. (beat) If they decide to attack, let them. They can't breach our walls. We'll beat them back again. (beat; to Priam) Yesterday the Greeks underestimated us. We should not return the favor today. Priam meditates on this conflicting advice. He stands and paces about the room. He turns to Archeptolemus.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: You're confident about the meaning of these omens?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: The desecration of his temple angers Apollo. The gods have cursed the Greeks. Two of their kings have already gone down to the dust. Priam continues pacing, hands clasped behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Prepare the army. We attack at noon.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: We're making a mistake, father. Father and son face each other across the long table.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Prepare the army.  117 118 lll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles' ship has already been hauled into the shallow water, ready to depart. Myrmidons climb the gangplank, carrying gear onto the ship's deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briseis sits in the cabin watching Achilles tie a hammock to a peg. Something has changed between them. She looks at him with undisguised tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Am I still your captive?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Captive is a harsh word. You're my guest.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: In Troy, guests can leave whenever they want.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Strange custom. Achilles takes her hand and inspects her uncalloused palms.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You've never worked the fields. Never chopped wood, never carried a milk pail. These are the hands of royalty. Achilles raises his own hands and shows them to her.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: My hands are gates to the underworld. (beat) All my life I've walked with Death. But I grow tired of his company. (beat) Come with me to Larissa. A hint of a smile crosses her lips.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Larissa. Is that where you're from? (beat) It's a pretty name. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I thought I'd never see it again. (beat) Before I left home my mother told me my fate.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: (sincere) She speaks with the gods?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: She knows things. (beat) She told me if I stayed home I'd have a long, peaceful life. And if I came to Troy, life would be short... but my name would never be forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: And you chose Troy.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: But what if Fate brought me here for another purpose? What if I had to go to war to find peace? (beat) To find you? She cups his face between her palms, pulls him closer, kisses his lips. For a moment they gaze at each other, until the sounds of WAR CRIES, HORNS, and BATTLE DRUMS fill the air. Achilles raises his head and listens, his face hardening. Briseis, alarmed, watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agamemnon, Nestor, and Odysseus exit the tent. The beach is a frenzy of activity. Thousands of men rush to their positions, hastily arming themselves. The kings look to the high dunes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector and his APOLLONIAN GUARDS, on horseback, crest the dunes and look down on the Greek encampment. 25,000 TROJAN FOOT SOLDIERS march behind Hector. He gives a signal. The force halts.  121

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GREEKS, plainly nervous, swarm to the long trench they've dug. The Trojans crushed them yesterday. Now they're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trojan ARCHERS pull their bows off their shoulders an notch their arrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greek archers notch their arrows. Odysseus stands with his ITHACANS, waiting to battle. A ery starts up on the far end of the Greek line and grows steadily louder. Odysseus looks in that direction. A glittering figure has stepped forth from the Myrmidon camp, clad in the beautiful and distinctive armor that every man in the Greek army recognizes.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Achilles. All down the Greek line we hear the cheer building to a roar. Agamemnon, hearing the commotion, turns and sees the shining warrior. He watches the spectacle with mixed emotions. Eudorus, standing with several Myrmidons, is thrilled by his leader's unexpected arrival.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Arm yourselves, men. The Myrmidons quickly and excitedly arm themselves. EXT. HIGH DUNES 121Вў The Trojans are not aware of this energy. Hector raises his sword and points at the Greeks. The Trojan army charges. When they are within range the Trojan archers release, sending a volley of arrows over the heads of their comrades. The Greek archers release at the same time. Two flocks of arrows cross in the sky and swoop down on the men below. Dozens of Greeks and Trojans fall to the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
