dialogues.text: But now the glorious bronzed figure of Achilles leaps ove the trench, sunlight reflecting off his polished armor. He raises his sword to the sky. A great, violent ROAR rises from the Greek army. When he runs toward the Trojans the Greeks jump from their positions and follow. The two armies collide. Unlike the grassy field the men fought on yesterday, today's battle takes place on the sand, and sand is everywhere. Horse hooves kick up clouds of sand. Men struggle for footing in the loose sand. Red blood puddles on the yellow sand. But much more is different than the terrain. Now the Greeks have a leader. The Myrmidons are at the forefront, battling with a ferocity most Trojans have never seen before. A Trojan OFFICER, spear raised, gallops toward the figure of Achilles. Before the Trojan can throw, Eudorus hurls his spear, catching the officer in the neck. The man goes down. Odysseus, immersed in combat, sees this. He hesitates for a moment and in his distraction is nearly cut down by an axe-wielding Trojan. They fight. After Odysseus dispatches the man, he looks back toward the glittering figure of Achilles. Something's making him uneasy. A Trojan swings his sword at the shining warrior, narrowl missing a clean decapitation. The Greek hero thrusts his spear and guts the Trojan. The Myrmidons surge forward, hacking their way through th Trojans. The Greek army steadily pushes the Trojans back, picking up more and more momentum. Now it is the Trojans who seem frightened, unsure where the Greeks found this intense spirit. Glaucus, the Trojan general, on horseback, shouts to Hector.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: The gods are with them today! We should fall back! Hector, fighting, does not answer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Myrmidons are getting closer to the elite Apollonians Hector notices them now. He notices the beautiful armor of their leader, notices the leader hop nimbly from the path of a charging Trojan and cut the man down.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: (to himself) Achilles. Hector goes after him. He grips the reins and guides his horse toward the Myrmidons. His Apollonians, clustered about him protectively, move in that direction as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two elite forces clash. These men are experts, wielding their spears and swords with superior skill. Hector's horse stumbles in the deep sand. Hector abandons his mount, leaping down to the beach, running for the shining warrior. A Myrmidon intercepts him. Their battle is quick-- Hector kills him with a sword thrust. Now he is face to face (or helmet to helmet) with the figure of glorious Achilles. The two men, breathing heavily from the combat, stand still for a moment. The intricately-worked bronze of Achilles' helmet, breastplate, and shield all shine bright. He's a difficult man to stare at for long. Now he charges, sword raised. They fight. And though the battle continues all around them, everyone seems to be aware of the duel taking place The shining warrior is quicker than Hector and lighter on his feet, swinging again and again, a blaze of bronze. Hector fights patiently, parrying the blows, waiting for an opening. The sword of Achilles whistles over Hector's head, swung so hard that the man wielding it cannot protect himself. Hector takes full advantage, swinging quickly, his blade carving the soft flesh just beneath Achilles' helmet. A long question mark of blood whips out of the cut throat The man falls. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everything seems to stop. Though the battle is still underway and thousands of individuals are still fighting for their lives, a collective gasp of despair comes from the Greeks. Odysseus, stunned, stares at the body on the ground. Hector stands next to the fallen man. He wedges the tip of his sword inside the bronze helmet and lifts it off. Patroclus is dying, trying to breathe as his throat flood with blood. His eyes are panicked. Hector stares down at the dying boy, at the blood-soaked SEASHELL NECKLACE. For a moment they stare at each other, the victorious prince of Troy and the dying boy in the sand. The sounds of Patroclus' gurgling breaths visibly upset the prince. With an anguished cry he raises his sword and brings it down. We don't see the blade hit, but the boy's suffering ends. Hector sees a stunned Odysseus standing nearby. The Greeks have pushed the Trojans back from the beach, onto the grassy inland plains, but now combat has halted.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Enough for one day? Odysseus nods. Hector calls out to Glaucus.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Arms down! Back to the city! Glaucus relays the call. Odysseus calls to his CAPTAINS.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Arms down! Arms down! To the beach! Odysseus sheathes his sword and approaches. He crouches by Patroclus and closes the dead boy's frightened eyes. Hector and Odysseus look at each other for a beat. Hector mounts his horse and leads his men home. The two sides retreat. Eudorus hurries over and kneels beside the dead boy.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: We were going to sail home at noon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: I don't think anyone's sailing home now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eudorus walks up to the ship, takes a few deep breaths, and calls to his commander.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Achilles! Achilles emerges from the ship's cabin and walks to the bow. He descends the gangplank to the beach. Briseis follows. Eudorus bows. Achilles examines his captain. Eudorus is sweaty and dirty, his hands caked with dried blood. His helmet is off but he still wears his armor.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You've been fighting.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: My lord --

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You violated my command.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: No, my lord. There was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: A mistake? I ordered the Myrmidons to stand down. You led them into combat?

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: I didn't lead them. Eudorus cannot meet his commander's gaze.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Who did?

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: We thought you did. Now Achilles can tell, staring at his captain's face, tha something is very wrong. He looks around the encampment. All the men returning from combat avoid looking at Achilles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Where's Patroclus?

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: We thought it was you, my lord. We -- he wore your armor. Your shield, your grieves, your helmet. (long beat) He's dead, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You're lying.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Never, my lord. Never. He looked like you. He even moved like you. We all followed --

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Lies.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: He fought well, my lord. With great courage. But Hector came after him. Achilles' nostrils are flared, his eyes narrowed.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: If I could have saved him -- Achilles hits Eudorus hard in the mouth. The captain falls to the sand. Achilles looms above him, fists clenched. Eudorus holds his mouth. Blood is already beginning to stream out.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Liar!

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: My lord, I saw him fall. Achilles seizes Eudorus by the hair and hauls him to his knees. He snatches Eudorus's sword and raises it. Briseis grabs Achilles' shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Don't! With his free hand Achilles grabs her throat. She claws at his wrist. Her feet spasm and kick inches off the ground. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eyes bulging, she stares at him. Whatever kindness she'd seen in his eyes before, whatever tenderness, it's gone now. Achilles drops her. She sags to the ground, gasping for breath, beginning to sob. Achilles releases Eudorus. The captain remains on his knees, watching his lord.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Dead?

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Hector cut his throat. Achilles walks to a dead campfire where the Myrmidons coo their dinner. He drops Eudorus's sword and kneels in the ashes, grabs handfuls of the soot, and blackens his face. Achilles stands, grabs the sword, and walks toward the sea. Everyone stares at him. He keeps walking as the waters lap at his ankles, his knees, his waist. The waves are high, crashing down on him, but Achilles does not turn from them. He swings the sword, chopping through the surf, slicing the crests off the waves, groaning as he fights. The soldiers on the beach stare at him. Achilles battles the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector, carrying a torch, leads Andromache through the lower garden, down a staircase descending from the shrine of Apollo to a door half-hidden by climbing vines. He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromache follows Hector into the palace's dark recesses

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me? Hector leads her until they reach a bronze-banded oak door. He opens the door, revealing the mouth of a dark tunnel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You remember how to get here?

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Next time you come, follow this tunnel. There's nowhere to turn, so you can't get lost. Keep walking.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Hector --

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: When you get outside you'll be on the south side of the Scamander River. Follow the river till you see Mount Ida. Keep Ida to your west, walk south, and you'll get to Lyrnessus. (beat) The Greeks won't go that far inland.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: You're frightening me. Hector stares into the darkness of the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Hector. (beat) Why are you telling me this?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: If I die --

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: If I die, I don't know how long the city will stand.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Don't say that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: If the Greeks get inside the walls, it's over. They'll kill all the men. Doesn't matter how old, they'll pull grandfathers from their beds and carve their lungs out.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Please --

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter how young. They'll throw the babies from the city walls. Andromache closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: The women they'll take for slaves. And that will be worse for you than dying.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Why are you saying these things?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I want you to be ready. I want you to get our boy, get him, and come here. Save as many others as you can, but you get here, you go down these stairs, and you run. (beat) Do you understand? She nods. The flickering flame of the taper throws giant shadows on the stone walls.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I killed a boy today. (beat) He was too young. Much too young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patroclus's body lies atop a massive funeral pyre, dresse in a simple white frock. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Achilles, clean now, all the soot washed away by the sea, scrubs Patroclus's face with a damp cloth. As fastidious as a mother, Achilles scrubs away the dried blood on the boy's lips, the dirt on his chin, the crusted blood on hi cut throat. He removes the SHELL NECKLACE. Agamemnon stands with Nestor in the crowd surrounding the pyre. Agamemnon watches the rite with ill-concealed pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: That boy just saved the war for us. Odysseus stands nearby. Melancholy and fatigue age his face. When the boy is clean Achilles pulls two COINS from a leather pouch. He places one coin over each of the dead boy's eyes. He kisses the boy's forehead and descends from atop the pyre. SEudorus hands him a torch and Achilles sets the pyre on fire.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 126
dialogues.text: We visit all our characters tonight. First Achilles, standing by the burning pyre, watching his cousin burn. Briseis sits nearby, watching Achilles watch the fire.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON 126A
dialogues.text: sits in his tent, carving X's on the map of Troy, his jaw taut as he ravages his painted enemy.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM 126B
dialogues.text: stands on a palace balcony, staring over his city.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR 126C
dialogues.text: stands by his son's crib, watching the boy sleep.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN 126D
dialogues.text: lies in bed. She hears a noise -- phhhthck! phhhthck! -- repeated over and over at brief intervals. She rolls out of bed and walks to the arched window.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN BELOW IN THE PALACE GARDEN 1265
dialogues.text: Paris practices his archery, shooting a target again and again by moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles, still standing in the same place, watches the remaining wood of the pyre collapse. He walks to his tent. On the way he passes Briseis. She has fallen asleep on the sand. He sees the bruises on her throat where his hand throttle her. As usual, the expression on his face is unreadable. He stares at her for another moment and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles finds Eudorus sleeping outside his tent.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Eudorus. Eudorus blinks, unsure where he is, then rouses himself a he recognizes his master's voice. He struggles to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: My lord.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I need my armor. Eudorus nods and rushes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eudorus helps Achilles prepare, clasping on his greaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While his wife and child sleep, Hector clasps on his greaves. INTERCUT between Achilles and Hector, clamping on their breastplates, arm guards, helmets, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small shrine on the palace grounds is designed so tha the summer sun rises above the sculpted Apollo's head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hector kneels in front of Apollo's statue, head bowed. When he raises his face he's almost looking into the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles exits his tent, fully armed. Eudorus is behind him. The SOLDIERS are beginning to stir and they stop in their activity now and stare at him. Two MYRMIDONS tether a CHARIOT to a large black HORSE. The work finished, they step back as Achilles hops into the chariot. Eudorus attempts to hop on behind him.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: No. Eudorus looks at his commander for a second and backs away.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: (to the Myrmidons) Rope. A Myrmidon hands him a coil of braided ROPE and retreats. Briseis steps into view. Her eyes are shadowed from lack of sleep. She stares up at Achilles and he looks at her. She looks fragile today, her pale throat purpled with bruises.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Don't go. Achilles watches her in silence.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Hector is my cousin. He's a good man. (beat) Take me to Larissa with you. But don't fight him. Please don't fight him. (beat) We could have a life together, but not if you choose this path. (beat) You can walk away from war. We can walk away. Achilles gazes at her, considering her words. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He tugs the reins and the horse begins trotting toward Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CROWDS start to fill the viewing areas above the city walls. Priam and his COUNSELORS sit below the blue canopy. Paris sits near them, but not with them. He doesn't look at anybody and people are careful to avoid looking at him Hector stands alone at one of the wall's turreted corners staring toward the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles rides his chariot across the vast grassy field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector watches the lone chariot approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles stops one hundred yards from the walls. He steps from the chariot and walks toward Troy, helmet by his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ARCHER standing beside Hector notches an arrow.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: No. Hector looks for Glaucus, standing farther down the wall. He gives the old general a hand signal. No attacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles stands alone in the vast field. He looks up at the Trojan CITIZENS staring down at him.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Hector! In the background, we see hundreds of GREEK SOLDIERS cres the high dunes.  139 140 126.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Hector! Louder and louder, his voice echoing above the silent city.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector walks over to his father. Achilles keeps bellowing his name. Hector kneels before his father and kisses his hand.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Father. Forgive me for any offenses. I've served you as best I could. Priam stands, beckons for Hector to rise, cups Hector's cheeks in his palms and kisses Hector's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: May the gods be with you. Hector hesitates for a moment, then bows and turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Hector! Hector turns back. Father and son look at each other. For a moment we think Priam will be unable to speak. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: No father ever had a better son. The words deeply move Hector. He bows again and moves on. He passes by Glaucus, who bows to the prince.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Apollo guard you, my prince. Hector claps the general's shoulder and keeps walking. He stops beside Paris. They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: You're the best man I know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You are a prince of Troy. Hector grips Paris's arm tighter and stares into his eyes

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I know you'll make me proud. Hector kisses Paris's forehead and continues on his way, pulling his helmet onto his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: waits for him above the stairs leading to the city gates. She holds their baby boy Scamandrius.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You remember what I told you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: You don't have to go. You don't --

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You remember what I told you. Andromache hasn't slept. Her hair is a wild tangle; her eyes are rimmed red. She nods. She holds her son up to his father. The boy doesn't see his father, he sees something terrifying, a man with a bronze face and a plum of horsehair. Scamandrius begins to CRY. Hector removes his helmet. Now the boy sees his father. He giggles and reaches out. Hector takes the boy in his arms and holds him. He kisses the boy's fuzzed head and closes his eyes for a moment. Finally he hands the baby back to Andromache. He smiles at his wife. She grabs him by the back of the head and presses his face to hers. Her mouth is open, her eyes closed, her body slack against his. Finally he disengages himself. He walks away from her. She and Scamandrius stare after him, but he never looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks down the long staircase descending from the walls. He stops at the massive city gates. The GATEMEN begin pulling the long chains that open the gates. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He senses someone behind him. He turns. Helen stands ten feet away, her unearthly beauty greater than ever. As the heavy gates rise, Helen and Hector stare at each other, never blinking, never looking away. Finally the gate is lifted. Hector bows to Helen and fits his helmet on his head. He leaves the city. Helen watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector walks toward Achilles. Everything is very quiet. The people on the walls are hushed. Even the birds seem reverent. Thousands and thousands of Greeks now line the high dunes making the valley an enormous amphitheater ringed with spectators from the dunes to the walls of Troy. Achilles stands motionless. The two men are alone on the great field. Hector stops twenty feet away from Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I've seen this moment in my dreams. Achilles, expressionless, stares at the prince.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I'll make a pact with you, with the gods as our witnesses. Let us pledge that the winner will allow the loser all the proper funeral rituals.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: There are no pacts between lions and men. Achilles tosses aside his helmet -- an insulting gesture, impugning Hector's combat skills.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Now you know who you're fighting. Hector pauses a moment before removing his own helmet and tossing it aside.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I thought it was you I was fighting yesterday. I wish it had been you. But I gave the dead boy the honor he -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You gave him the honor of your sword. (beat) You won't have eyes tonight. You won't have ears, or a tongue. You'll wander the underworld, blind, deaf, and dumb. And all the dead will know: this is Hector, the fool who thought he killed Achilles. Achilles draws his sword. Hector draws his. They charge. We've seen extraordinary fighting before, but we've never seen this -- a prowess so extreme as to be hypnotic. Two better swordsmen have never clashed. All their lives, all their training and past battles, have led to this moment. Nothing is wasted. No flourishes or balletic leaps or spins. Every swing is a death blow countered. The rapidity of the exchange is breathless. The bronze blades hiss as they split the air. They swing with such power that sparks fly whenever a sword scrapes shield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agamemnon, Nestor, and Odysseus stand with their men. For the moment all machinations and intrigues are forgotten. Each of them knows this fight will be remembered forever, and each watches quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector lunges forward and from our angle it appears that has skewered Achilles. Hector's face is inches from Achil Achilles appears unperturbed. Hector looks down. Achilles has trapped him, allowing Hector's sword to miss his side by inches and then clamping down on Hector's sword arm. Hector tries to yank his sword free but cannot. Achilles stabs at Hector's face and Hector ducks at the last moment, the sword point puncturing the air above his head. Achilles releases Hector and takes another mighty swing.  144 145 146 130.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromache sits with Scamandrius, her back against the wall. She cannot watch. Her boy, blissfully unaware, coos happily and plays with his mother's long hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles, sensing the advantage, moves in a step too close. Hector sees an opening and slashes. Achilles jumps back at the last possible moment, but Hector's blade gouges ou a long strip of bronze from Achilles' breastplate. Both men swing. Their swords lock and for a moment everything is still. Achilles' face is inches from Hector's. Hector is sweating and breathing heavily. Achilles is not. Achilles shoves Hector and relaunches his attack. While Hector still fights ably, he's clearly tiring. As Achilles' blows force Hector back, the prince steps on a rock, trips, and falls. Achilles stands above him.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Get up, prince of Troy. I won't let a stone take my glory. Hector stands. He knows his energy is fading fast. So he spends everything on one last try. He charges, swinging with explosive fury, putting all his might into each blow When the barrage is finished and Hector pauses for a breath, he sees that Achilles, unhurt, has parried everything. Now Achilles bores in, swinging. Hector blocks and blocks, but doesn't have the stamina for a new assault. Achilles lunges. Hector raises his shield. The sword plunges through the seven layers of oxhide, plunges through the hammered bronze of the shield, the bronze of the breastplate, all the way into Hector's heart. Hector looks down at the blade. He looks at Achilles. There is no mercy or remorse on the man's face. Hector falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priam reacts as if he received the blow, clutching at his chest and reeling backward. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Paris presses forward, gripping the edge of the wall so hard his knuckles turn white. Andromache hears the GROANS of the crowd. She covers her ears and clamps her eyes shut. Scamandrius stares at her, baffled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector lies on his back. Achilles pulls out his bloody sword and walks to his chariot. Hector blinks. The sun, now high in the sky, is blinding. Hector stares into the sun and dies. Silence. Silence everywhere. No victory cry from the Greeks. Achilles returns in the chariot. He jumps out with the coil of rope. He ties Hector's ankles together, then ties the other end of the rope to the back of the chariot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something hardens in Paris's face. Whatever callowness we've seen before seems to ebb away as he watches Achille abuse Hector's body. Priam and his subjects watch in horror.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: My boy... my boy... Andromache sits against the wall, knees tucked against he chest, face against her knees. Scamandrius begins to cry. Helen kneels by Andromache. She picks up the baby and soothes him. Helen takes Andromache's hand. Andromache looks up. Her eyes are a terrible thing to see.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Let's go inside. Andromache allows Helen to pull her to her feet. Helen, holding the baby in one arm, guides Andromache away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles whips his horse and the chariot starts rolling, dragging Hector through the grass.  150 151 152 153 154 132.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priam's legs give out. Glaucus and Paris catch him before he falls and carry him toward the shade beneath the blue canopy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles rides his chariot over the crest of the dune. The Greek army parts like the Red Sea, solemn and silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles rides into camp. The Greek soldiers gather round to stare at Hector's body. Achilles doesn't look at anyone. He unties the rope and hauls Hector by hand across the sands. Odysseus stands nearby, amongst the men. A few of the soldiers laugh, seeing the Trojan prince laid low.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1
dialogues.text: He doesn't look so glorious now. Odysseus turns and glares at the soldier, who shuts his mouth. Odysseus walks away. Achilles drags Hector's body to his tent, dumps him there and walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briseis kneels in the center of the tent, palms pressed together, eyes lowered in prayer. She opens her eyes and looks up when Achilles walks in. He looks more beast than man, splattered with Hector's blood. Briseis sees Achilles' face and knows what happened. For the first time her strength deserts her. She looks very young, very childlike as she begins to cry He regards her for a moment before going to his bedding and lying on his back. We stay on his face as Briseis weeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All but the sentries are sleeping. No campfires burn as a fat moon rises above the sea.  155 156 157 133.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles, now clean, sits in the center of the tent, sharpening his sword. Briseis sits in a far corner. She's been crying for hours, her eyes red and swollen.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: You lost your cousin. And now you've taken mine. Achilles looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: When does it end? Achilles continues sharpening his sword.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: It never ends. Briseis stares at him for a moment and leaves the tent. Achilles quits his sharpening. Now there is nothing but silence, nothing but a bronze sword for company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briseis sits on the beach, facing the moonlit sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles still sits alone, his eyes empty. He hears a rustling at the tent flap. An old man wearing a hooded robe steps inside. The old man pulls his hood down. It's Priam.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Who are you? Priam seems physically hurt by the sight of Achilles. For a moment it seems he will collapse again. But he wills himself onward, walking to Achilles' chair. He sinks to his knees, takes Achilles' hands, and kisses them. Achilles observes all this with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: I have endured what no one on earth has endured before. I kissed the hands of the man who killed my son.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Priam? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Priam nods. Achilles stands, helping the old man to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: How did you get in here, old king? The sentries --

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: I know my own country better than the Greeks, I think.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You're a brave man. If Agamemnon knew you were here, he'd have your head on a spit.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Do you really think death frightens me now? I watched my eldest son die, watched you drag his body behind your chariot. Priam stares at Achilles, and for the first time since we've known him, Achilles looks away.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Give him back to me. He deserves the honor of a proper burial. You know that. Give him to me.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: He killed my cousin.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: He thought it was you. He defended his country. How many cousins have you killed? How many sons and fathers and brothers and husbands? How many, brave Achilles? (beat) I knew your father. He died before his time. But he was lucky not to live long enough to see his son fall. Achilles does not respond. We cannot read his expression. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: You've taken everything from me. My eldest son, heir to my throne, defender of my kingdom. (beat) I can't change what happened. It's the will of the gods. But give me this small mercy. Achilles looks into the old man's eyes. Priam tries to blink back his tears but fails.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: I loved my boy from the moment he opened his eyes till the moment you closed them. (beat) Let me wash his body. Let me say the prayers. Let me place two coins on his eyes for the boatman.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: If I let you walk out of here, if I let you take him, it doesn't change anything. You're still my enemy in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: You're still my enemy tonight. But even enemies can show respect. Achilles nods.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I admire your courage, old man. You're a better king than the one leading this army. Meet me outside in a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles, carrying a torch and a white shroud, walks to the spot where Hector's body lies. He crouches beside the dead prince. Death has not robbed Hector's face of its dignity. A small sand crab approaches the body and Achilles shoos it away. He shoves the butt end of the torch into the sand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Achilles rubs his eyes with his hand and takes several deep breaths. When he removes his hand, we see something remarkable: Achilles' eyes are wet with tears. For a moment he seems unsure what to do. Finally he begins wrapping the white sheet around Hector's body.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: We'll meet again soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priam, deep in his grief, sits with his head bowed. He hears noiases outside. He stands and exits the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles gently loads Hector's body, now wrapped in the shroud, onto a moonlit chariot. Priam walks to the chariot. Four Myrmidons, keeping a respectful distance, stand guard.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Your son was the best I've fought. I want you to know that. (beat) In my country the funeral games last twelve days.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: It's the same in my country.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Then no Greek will attack Troy for twelve days. The prince deserves that honor. Achilles, hearing footsteps, turns. Briseis emerges from the shadows. Priam is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Briseis? Priam wraps his arms around her, thrilled she's alive.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: We thought you were dead, little swan. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: After a moment Briseis turns and looks at Achilles. Nobody speaks for a long beat. Tears shine in Briseis' eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You'll be safe behind the Trojan walls. Achilles reaches into his tunic and pulls out the SHELL NECKLACE that Patroclus had worn. He fastens it around her delicate neck, where the purple bruises are still visible. He speaks quietly to her, too softly for Priam to hear.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: If I hurt you -- it's not what I wanted. (long beat) You gave me one night of peace in a lifetime of war. She stares up at him, her young face mapped with conflicting emotions. Finally, Achilles turns to Priam.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Go. No one will stop you, you have my word. Priam gets in the chariot. Briseis still looks at Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Come, my girl. Priam reaches down and helps her onto the chariot. He seizes the reins and they're off, the Myrmidons escorting them to safety. Achilles stares at Briseis until she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agamemnon paces about his tent in a murderous fury. Odysseus, Nestor and several AIDES stand in attendance.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: (shouting) Achilles makes a secret pact and I have to honor it?! What treason is this? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (fairly spitting the words) Consorting with the enemy king! Giving him twelve days of peace. Peace! Their prince is dead; their army is leaderless. This is the time to attack!

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: Even with Hector gone, we have no way to breach their walls. They can wait ten years for us to leave.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I will smash their walls to the ground. If it costs me forty thousand Greeks, Zeus hear me, I will smash their walls to the ground. Nestor and Odysseus exchange troubled glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odysseus sits with his ITHACANS by the fire. The men eat a breakfast of grilled fish. The soldier sitting beside Odysseus whittles with a sharp knife. Odysseus watches the man work. The Soldier notices his king's attention. He smiles and holds up a small WOOD HORSE.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: For my boy back home. Odysseus nods, never taking his eyes off the toy horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of Greeks eat breakfast on the beach. Several of them turn to watch Odysseus, who rushes to Agamemnon's tent and disappears inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giant pyre has been built in the city square. Thousands of CITIZENS are gathered around to watch. No crowd has ever been more silent. The city has lost its favorite son. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hector lies atop the pyre, dressed in a woven robe of white and gold, his hair washed and oiled, his skin gleaming and clean. His face is undamaged. Two coins rest above his eyes. Priam stands at the base of the pyre, holding a lit torch His hand trembles. He is unable to light the pyre. Finally Paris grips his father's shoulder. Paris takes the torch from Priam and lights the kindling. Helen, Andromache, and baby Scamandrius sit nearby. Andromache's face is completely blank. She stares dully at the quickening fire. Helen holds Scamandrius in her lap. The boy plays with the WOOD LION his father made for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By torchlight, we see Greeks stripping planks from two burnt shells of warships. Others pry spikes out of the fortifications. Odysseus watches the men carry the planks and bundles of spikes to an ever-growing pile. Achilles approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Wily Odysseus. You've found a way to make the sheep invite the wolves over for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: This is war.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Agamemnon will kill them all. Men, women, children -- all of them. You know that. Achilles walks away. Odysseus follows him.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: I'm the king of Ithaca, not Troy. My loyalty is to Ithaca. If this plan works, the war ends in a night. And my men can sail home to their wives. Achilles keeps walking, Odysseus pacing after him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: It's not Troy you're worried about, is it? It's one Trojan. One Trojan girl. Achilles halts. He stares at Odysseus for a long count.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I've always liked you. But if that girl dies because of your plan, you will never sail home to your wife. Achilles turns and leaves. Odysseus takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles arrives at his tent and finds Eudorus polishing his armor. Eudorus jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Eudorus. (beat) Forgive me. Eudorus blinks. No one has ever heard these words from Achilles' mouth before.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I should never have struck you. You've been a loyal friend all your life.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: I hope I never disappoint you again.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Rouse the men. You're taking them home.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Aren't you coming with us?

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I've got one more battle to fight. Eudorus hesitates, watching his lord. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: She's worth fighting for. We'll march behind you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: All that's left is the slaughter. I don't want to see my men fouled with children's blood. (beat) Go, Eudorus. This is the last order I give you. After a long pause, Eudorus bows deeply to his commander.

dialogues.speaker: EUDORUS
dialogues.text: Fighting for you has been my life's honor. Achilles grips his lieutenant's shoulder and strides away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve days later. The SENTRIES are at their posts, warming their hands over a brazier. The sky begins to lighten. Sentry 1 stares down to the sea. He hurries to the edge of the tower and squints into the morning fog. Sentry 2 looks at him and then joins him.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY 1
dialogues.text: They're gone. It's true. All the Greek ships are gone from the beach. All the tents have been struck, all the chariots taken away, every last man -- gone. Nothing's left on the beach but a strange wooden structure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priam, Paris, Glaucus, Archeptolemus, and Velior, all on horseback, lead the Apollonian Guard onto the beach. The soldiers -- still wary of an ambush -- surround their leaders, protecting them from attack. The Trojan leaders dismount. Slowly they approach a WOODEN HORSE standing forty feet high. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The beach is deserted save for the bones of burnt-out ships, a few stray arrows, the remnants of the camp fires and corpses -- dozens of Greek bodies scattered in the sands. Each of the cadavers is covered with large black sores. The Trojans inspect the bodies, keeping a wary distance.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Plague.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Don't get too close, my king.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: This is the will of the gods. Everyone turns to look at the high priest.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: They desecrated the temple of Apollo and Apollo desecrate their flesh. The Greeks could fight our swords and arrows, but they can't fight the god's plague. Glaucus shakes his head and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: They thought they'd come here and sack our city in a day. And look at them now, fleeing across the Aegean. Priam stares up at the great horse.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: An offering to Poseidon. The Greeks are praying for a safe return home.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: I hope the Sea God spits on their offering and lets them all drown at the bottom of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: This is a gift. We should bring it to the temple of Poseidon. All the men stare at the towering horse. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I think we should burn it.

dialogues.speaker: VELIOR
dialogues.text: Burn it? My prince -- it's a gift to the gods.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: The prince is right. I'd burn all of Greece if I had a big enough torch.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: I warn you, good men. Be careful what you insult. Our beloved prince Hector had sharp words for the gods and a day later Achilles! sword cut him down. Priam turns to look at the high priest.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: (glaring at Archeptolemus) Burn it, father. Archeptolemus ignores Paris and speaks directly to Priam.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: Forgive me, my king. I mean no disrespect. But I don't want to see any more princes of Troy incur the gods' wrath. All the men look at Priam. He stares at the massive horse.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: I will not watch another son die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of Trojan soldiers tugging long ropes pull the massive horse across the grassy plain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers drag the horse through the gates. The citizens of Troy watch from atop the walls and inside the city proper.  171 172 173 144.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horse now stands near the statue of Poseidon wielding his trident, beside his temple on one corner of the city square. The square is crowded and jubilant. Soldiers and citizens celebrate their great victory, drinking wine in the streets, waving torches and Trojan flags, singing songs. Paris and Helen sit on the palace stairs, watching the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Look at them. You'd think their prince had never died. Helen takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You're their prince. (beat) Make your brother proud. Her comment echoes the words Hector spoke to him before his death. Paris nods solemnly. Helen rests her head on his shoulder. They sit quietly as the crowds sing in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An abandoned DOG lopes along the beach, stopping to sniff each Greek corpse. Finding one dead man he seems to recognize, the dog licks the cadaver's face. The "sore" on the dead face is licked clean. The sores are masterful forgeries, applied with squid ink and dried blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TROJAN RIDER on horseback trots south, away from distan Troy. He looks toward the Hellespont. Something catches his eye. He frowns and guides his mount toward the cliff's edge. We rise above him and look down at the Hellespont. By the light of the moon, nearly one thousand GREEK WARSHIPS harbor in the deserted bay. The rider stares at the ships in horror.  174

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The square is empty now, all the revelers gone home. The wood horse waits in the moonlight. We witness something strange: ropes, anchored inside the horse, fall to the ground. Soldiers emerge from the horse and slide silently down th ropes: Achilles, Odysseus and ten other Greek soldiers. None of them wear the bright, clanking bronze armor. Their swords and spears are wrapped in lambskins. Odysseus leads a team of Ithacans across the square. Quiet as shadows, they creep up on the sentries guarding the main gate. Another team moves toward the guard towers. Achilles stands alone in the dark square, watching his compatriots set off on their deadly missions. Finally he turns and moves in the opposite direction, toward the palace. He's on a different mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Ithacans cut the gate sentries' throats. The soldiers begin pulling the chains to raise the city gates.

dialogues.speaker: THE TROJAN RIDER 1743
dialogues.text: gallops to Troy. The Greeks see him coming and look to Odysseus for guidance. The rider, still at some distance, shouts to the men at the gates.

dialogues.speaker: TROJAN RIDER
dialogues.text: They're still here! The Greeks are still here! They sailed up the Hellespont! Odysseus hurls his spear. It flies through the bars of the gate and into the rider's throat, knocking him from his horse. The horse, panicked, gallops away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the sentries, hearing the commotion, wakes up. Groggy, he looks over the edge of the tower -- into a Greek's face. The Greek, one hand on the ladder, stabs the sentry. Another Greek crawls into the tower and kills the second sentry.  176 177 178

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greeks pull the gates open. They wave their torches, a signal. Looking into the distance, we see something shifting in the darkness, coming closer and closer. The Greek army, shadows in the dark, charges toward the city at a sprint, silent. Thousands upon thousands of warriors running quietly as panthers. Like water bursting through a dam, the Greeks blast through the gates, swords and spears raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briseis leans against a balustrade, staring toward the beach. She wears a blue robe and the seashell necklace. She hears NOISES from the city gates and turns. On a flagpole above the highest guard tower, the Trojan flag i burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All over the city, the Greeks carry out their raids, killing sentries at their posts, setting buildings on fir with torches, opening the stable doors and shooing all th frightened horses into the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon the city is in chaos. Fires burn out of control. Screams begin to echo down the alleyways, first just a few, then more and more, until it seems the entire city i screaming.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES 178B
dialogues.text: runs through the burning city, keeping to the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priam stands on the balcony, watching his beautiful city burn, watching the destruction of his life's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trojan soldiers begin to straggle in, but they're not prepared for this. Many are unarmed and all look terrified. Four Trojans run to the armory doors and throw them open. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They dive back as a BLAST of heat rushes out the door. The armory is aflame, fires eating at the wood-beamed ceiling, devouring thousands of spears on their racks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FAMILIES of terrified civilians stagger through the streets in their bedclothes. MOTHERS clutch their CHILDREN's hands. OLD WOMEN flee their burning buildings. The women scream when they see Achilles running toward them, sword drawn. But pillaging is the last thing on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briseis hurries through the hallways. Outside, past the archways, the white buildings of Troy are on fire. We hear the screaming of a dying city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agamemnon stands in the very center of Troy, head tilted back, watching with delight as the beautiful city burns

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I promised you, brother. (yelling to his troops) Burn it all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris suits up for battle. He grabs his bow and quiver of arrows. Helen watches him. Andromache enters the room, Scamandrius in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: We have to run.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: I'll show you. Paris looks at Helen.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Come, my love. Come with us.  185 186 187 148.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odysseus battles his way down the street, leading the Greeks against a contingent of half-armored Trojans. The Trojans are too dazed to offer much resistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromache, carrying her baby and a lit torch, leads Helen, Paris, and other WOMEN and CHILDREN down the staircase to the vine-tangled door. Andromache pulls it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromache leads the Trojans to the bronze-banded door. She opens the door, revealing the dark tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: It's a long walk. Helen and the others enter the tunnel. Paris does not. He stands just outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I stay.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: My father will never abandon the city. I can't leave him.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: The city is dead! They're burning it to the ground! Paris looks at the huddled refugees. They're a timid lot, terrified and weak. AENEAS (14) looks stronger and braver than the rest. He's supporting his BLDERLY FATHER.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: AENEAS
dialogues.text: Aeneas.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Do you know how to use a sword? Aeneas nods. Paris pulls out the sword of Troy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: The sword of Troy. I wasn't so good with it, but it's a fine sword. (beat) As long as it's in a Trojan's hand, our people have a future. (hands sword to Aeneas) Protect them, Aeneas. Find them a new home.

dialogues.speaker: AENEAS
dialogues.text: I will. Andromache touches Paris's arm.

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMACHE
dialogues.text: Briseis wasn't in her room.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I'll find her. Andromache kisses him. She turns and leads the way through the tunnel. The Trojans follow. Aeneas bows to Paris and helps his father as their long journey begins.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I'll stay with you. Paris pushes her gently toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Don't leave me. Please don't leave me.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: How could you love me if I ran now?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Please --

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: We will be together again. In this world or the next, we will be together. He kisses her hard, pushes her through the door and close it. He kisses the wood, turns and runs toward the battle.  188 189 190 150.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briseis runs down a long corridor. We hear cries from the massacre outside.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Paris? Andromache? She stops mid-stride. A riderless WHITE HORSE rounds the corner and bolts toward her, eyes crazed, muzzled foamed with spittle. Briseis backs against the wall. The terrified horse gallops past her.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Achilles scales the high wall surrounding the palace and jumps to the other side. He's spotted by an Apollonian. The Guard charges. Achilles cracks him in the face with the hilt of his sword. The Guard falls. Achilles grabs him and hauls him to his feet, sword at his throat.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Briseis -- where is she? (louder) Where is she?!

dialogues.speaker: APOLLONIAN
dialogues.text: I don't know... please, I have a son. Achilles shoves him away.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Get him out of Troy. The Guard, stunned to find himself alive, finally runs. Achilles rushes into the palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odysseus and his men fight their way up the palace stairs The Trojans resist heroically. They die heroically. Agamemnon stands behind his troops, hollering orders.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: No one escapes! No one!  191

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside we hear the screams and battle cries. Glaucus stands with fifty of his men, the last line of defense. He walks through their ranks, clasping hands with each man.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: You men are soldiers. Leading you has been an honor. Paris runs into the hall. Glaucus smiles and clasps hands with the prince. Glaucus addresses the men.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: The boatman is waiting for us. I say, let him wait a little longer! The men roar as the Greeks spill into the reception hall.

dialogues.speaker: THE TROJANS 191A
dialogues.text: attack. For a few moments they drive the Greeks back. Paris notches an arrow and fires. A Greek falls, an arrow through his throat. But too many Greeks pour through the doors. The Trojans fight bravely, especially Paris, who fires quickly and accurately. Odysseus engages Glaucus and quickly kills the old general. The surviving Trojans retreat farther into the palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of Greeks charge into the hall, seizing whatever treasures they can carry and smashing whatever they can't Priam, armed with a sword, rushes into the hall. He sees two Greeks grabbing small GOLD FIGURINES of the gods from their wall sconces. He raises his sword.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Have you no honor? No respect for the gods? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Before Priam can move forward he is speared from behind, the spearhead tearing through his back and out his chest. He falls. Agamemnon stands above him. He yanks his spear free.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I wanted you alive, old king. I wanted you to watch your city burn.

dialogues.speaker: PRIAM
dialogues.text: Please... the children... spare the innocents...

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Let Hades decide who's innocent. He walks away, leaving the old man to die alone on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archeptolemus kneels beneath the statue of Zeus. He stands when a band of Greek soldiers close in on him.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHEPTOLEMUS
dialogues.text: Beware, my friends. I am a servant of the gods. A soldier chops him down and hurls the priest's body over the balustrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briseis runs into the garden, looking for a friendly face No one's in sight. She runs to the lower garden. She doesn't notice Agamemnon, stained with Priam's blood, standing in an archway of the burning palace, watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles races through the palace, ignoring the fire and smoke, searching the faces of the terrified women he passes.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Briseis! Briseis!  196 197 198 153.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briseis kneels by Apollo's statue, ignoring the inferno around her.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Too late for prayer, priestess. Briseis does not look up. Agamemnon grabs her long hair and pulls her to her feet. He holds his sword to her throat. Two of his BODYGUARDS stand behind him.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: Your parents should have taught you to stand for a king.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: They did.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: You wore a white robe when I last saw you. No more? Did brave Achilles ruin you for the temple? Briseis does not look at him or answer. He pulls her close.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: I almost lost this war because of your little romance. I want to taste what Achilles tasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles, running past the bodies of dead Trojans, looks through an archway and sees Briseis in Agamemnon's hands. He dashes outside.

dialogues.speaker: AGAMEMNON
dialogues.text: (whispering in Briseis' ear) You'll be my slave in Mycenae. A Trojan priestess scrubbing my floors. And at night -- He tears her robe. Briseis pulls her hand out of her sleeve. She's holding a ceremonial DAGGER. She drives the dagger into the side of Agamemnon's neck. His eyes bulge. She rams the dagger deeper. Agamemnon falls to the ground, clutching at his neck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The bodyguards stare at their dying king in disbelief. Briseis runs. The bodyguards pursue her. Briseis stumbles and falls. She looks behind her. One of the bodyguards raises his sword, ready to split Briseis i half. Before he can bring down his sword, his head flies from his shoulders. As the man falls, Achilles whirls around and dispatches the other bodyguard, bronze sword glittering in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris, bow in hand, looks out an archway to the garden an sees Achilles -- the man who killed his brother -- splattered with blood, sword in hand, standing over Briseis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achilles looks down at Agamemnon's corpse, lying in puddled blood a few feet away. He looks back to Briseis.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Come with me. Before she can answer her eyes go wide. She sees Paris, in the upper garden, notching an arrow.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Come. I'll protect you. Paris pulls back the catgut string. Briseis screams:

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: No! Paris fires. Briseis's scream distracts him -- the arrow sails off course, hitting Achilles above his heel, tearin through the tendon. Achilles staggers, turns, and sees Paris. Achilles snarls and heads for him. Paris shoots again. Achilles tries to dodge but the torn tendon in his heel slows him down. The arrow rips through his side. Achilles keeps limping forward.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Stop! Paris! Stop! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Paris releases another arrow. Now Achilles doesn't even try to dodge. The arrow sinks deep into his chest. Achilles keeps coming. He knows this is the end. A small smile crosses his face. He has waited for this moment his entire life. He marches toward his destiny. Paris notches another arrow. His hands are shaking but he fires again. This one drills deep into Achilles' belly.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Stop! Achilles keeps coming. Paris reaches for another arrow. His quiver is empty. Aeneas has his sword. The palace around them is burning, lighting their faces. Blood pours from Achilles' wounds. The arrow shafts stick out of him. Any other man would have already fallen. But he keeps coming, relentless, his face a mask of grim purpose. Briseis runs in front of her cousin Paris and shields him with her body. Achilles lifts his bloody sword.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: No more. Briseis does not move. For several seconds the great warrior and the young girl stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: No more killing. Achilles looks at the seashell necklace she wears.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: No more. Achilles raises his sword and brings it down hard, buryin its bronze blade in the soil of the garden.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: No more. He reaches out and rubs the shells of her necklace.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: My mother made this necklace. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He sinks to a sitting position on the grass. He pulls the arrows out of his body and tosses them aside. Briseis sits beside him. She cradles his head in her arms while all Troy burns around them.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: You have to get out.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Shh.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Get out. She kisses his lips, running her fingers across his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: There's no way out. Achilles stares at Paris.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: There's always a way out for the princes. Paris tries to lift Briseis to her feet but she refuses.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Briseis. She leans closer. He's losing too much blood, his strength is fading, but he summons his remaining energy t speak.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: I chose this night... but you will see the sun again. I want you to live. Her face is full of sorrow and love. He touches her lips, his fingers trembling as his body fails. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Live. She doesn't want to go but he pushes her gently away. Finally she nods.

dialogues.speaker: BRISEIS
dialogues.text: Because of you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 201 202 She turns and follows Paris down the stairs toward escape Achilles watches her intently until he sees she's safely away. He takes a deep breath and closes his eyes. Hordes of rampaging Greeks storm the garden, burning anything that will burn, hollering their victory cries. Achilles sits alone in the garden. He shivers, hugging himself for warmth, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greeks are victorious. The beautiful city of Troy is a ruin. Trojan PRISONERS are led off in chains. Greek soldiers carry gold treasures from the lavish temples and palace. Funeral pyres fill the square. One pyre, taller than the rest, rises in the center of the square. Odysseus stands atop the highest pyre, staring down at the body of Achilles. For a long time Odysseus looks at the dead man's face. He knows the world will never see another Achilles. Finally he reaches inside his tunic, pulls out two coins, and places them over Achilles' eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ODYSSEUS
dialogues.text: Find peace, my brother. Odysseus climbs down from the pyre. A LIEUTENANT hands him a torch and Odysseus starts the fire. The dry wood quickly catches. Black smokes rises toward the circling crows. CLOSE on Odysseus as he watches his friend burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small band of Trojans marches east toward the rising sun. Helen and Paris, Andromache and Scamandrius, Aeneas and the others -- alive. They walk toward Mount Ida. Briseis walks behind the others. She stops for a moment and looks back toward the ruins of Troy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Briseis for a beat. And then we see what she sees: the black smoke from Achilles' pyre rising above the smoldering city, rising above the circling crows, and finally fading away into the deep blue sky. FADE OUT.
